speech.para: So we find two Ministers of the Grown occupying their time in writing letters and examining the law to discover whether or not a small school boy has been committing an offence by running messages on .Saturday mornings. That is a terrible state of affairs, but it is only one of many hundreds of things that are happening in this country every day, owing to the application of impossible and impracticable regulations, and their administration - I am not referring to the political heads at the moment - by theorists who have had no experience of the job, or by individuals who are endeavouring to foist their own pet schemes and theories upon this country. I say emphatically that many of these regulations have been necessitated by the Government's action in replacing ordinary sound finance with a set of artificial conditions. Even although the Government did not take action in 1941, in 1942 at the latest it should have adopted schemes supplemental to its "budget proposals.

Because of the short time at my disposal, and in view of the fact that other more suitable opportunities will be presented at a later stage, I shall not dwell on the details of the two major proposals that the Opposition has urged upon the Government, namely, the adoption of a plan of post-war credits, and the application of the " pay-as-you-go " taxation system to provide for the introduction of modern taxation methods such as those already in operation in Canada and the United States of America. I have asked honorable members opposite consistently to consider at least these two major reforms in their financial pro- posals, but so far no progress in that direction has been made. The Government has pumped out money for expenditure on the war to the amount pf many millions of pounds, apparently in the expectation that that money would be voluntarily loaned back to it. Sometimes it is loaned back, but only by comparatively few people. By far the great majority of people either put their money into savings banks where, of course, it is of some value for war purposes or, they spend it, with the result that the unfortunate conditions to which I have referred are set up. These people are not only causing embarrassment to the Government, but also they are causing embarrassment to their fellow citizens. They are causing constantly increasing prices, all because the Government has refused to adopt as its policy something that would undoubtedly lead to the proper regulation of moneys as they passed from the Government to the hands of the people. In a few days from now, the Government will complete another financial year, and in the light of the periodical statements that have been made, it would not be out of place for me to endeavour to estimate the position that will arise. In September last, the Treasurer told us that war expenditure for the current financial year would amount to £440,000,000. Then, in February of this year he gave an amended estimate of £540,000,000. Now, according to the statement of the Prime Minister yesterday, the figure will reach £560,000,000. That, of course, is war expenditure only. In addition, there is ordinary departmental expenditure, expenditure on social services and other very proper expenditure totalling £112,000,000. These figures combined give a grand total of £672,000,000. As against that, receipts are expected to amount to £262,000,000-1 am using a figure constructed upon the statement made to the House by the Treasurer in February last- so that there will be a deficiency of £410,000,000. Any figures which I shall use now are subject to what the Treasurer will tell the House a few weeks hence. Loans will return to the Government approximately £200,000,000 and the central banking system will provide £23 0,000,000 worth of credit. Those two amounts total £410,000,000, which is the deficiency for the current financial year. [Extension of time granted.] The total amount of central bank credit which will be issued by the 30th June, 1943, will be approximately £275,000,000. My figures might be incorrect by a few millions of pounds, but I am speaking of a principle and am not endeavouring to state a mathematical sum. I am reconstructing the position from the latest information available to me; but I believe that my figures will be approximately correct. By the 30th June, the treasury-bill issue will be £275,000,000 and that figure does not include a total of £40,000,000 for old treasury-bills issued on behalf of the States. With the exception of less than £2,000,000, the whole of this sum has been raised since July, 1941. That position is bad enough; but what appals me is the consideration of the future. This system of disregarding any consideration except the bridging of the difference between revenue and expenditure by central bank credit is having a snowball effect, and the snowball gathers in size.

What of the next financial year which will commence on the 1st July, 1943? I predict that the Government will not present a budget to this Parliament before it goes to the country. Personally, I do not consider that there is any great need for the presentation of the budget, because the figures can be reconstructed. Some of my figures may prove to be incorrect, but even so the Treasurer's own estimates were incorrect by £100,000,000 between last September and February.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member does not imply that that is the fault of the Treasurer.

- Certainly not. I realize the Treasurer's difficulties. I am criticizing the system and the lack of policy, and none of ray remarks should be regarded as personal criticism of either the Treasurer or the Minister for War Organization of Industry (Mr. Dedman). The position can be assessed in a manner sufficiently accurate for my purposes, in order to give an indication of what we shall experience in the next financial year. I. have already told the

speech.para: House that war expenditure for the financial year 1942-43 will be £560,000,000. Am I unreasonable in saying that during the next twelve months it will be £650,000,000? War expenditure is constantly rising. The Treasurer will not surprise me if he announces at the end of the next financial year that the expenditure is £750,000,000. In order to keep the position within reasonable limits and to avoid exaggeration, I shall estimate that the expenditure will be £650,000,000, and that ordinary expenditure will be the same as last year's figure, namely, £112,000,000. Thus, the total expenditure for the year will be £762,000,000, against which the Treasurer's receipts will be £300,000,000. Receipts from taxation will be considerably increased as the result of the higher rates that applied from the 1st April last. I shall assume that the Treasury will still receive taxes from other incomes in the same quantum as during the last year, although I doubt it very much, because the actions. of other departments of government have tended seriously to reduce the income which will be available to the Treasury for taxation purposes in the next financial year. If receipts total £300,000,000, the difference between expenditure and revenue will be £462,000,000. In saying that, I make no secret of my conviction that the deficiency will be considerably more than £462,000,000. I shall be surprised if it is not considerably in excess of £500,000,000. But the most favorable construction that can be placed upon the position is that Australia during the new financial year will use £275,000,000 of additional central bank credit and by the end of June, 1944, will have doubled the amount of central bank credit that is at present in circulation. If the present Government remains in office until the 30th June, 1944, it will have built up in less' than three years about £550,000,000 of central bank credit. Honorable members should bear in mind that that total is a conservative estimate. My own opinion is that it will be £600,000,000 or possibly £650,000,000. I want to make it clear that the Opposition has never claimed that, if it had been in office, it could have avoided the use of central bank, credit. I make that statement because on a previous occasion, the Treasurer implied that we considered that we could manage without central bank credit. We could not. I quoted to him from the budgets of the previous Treasurer, Mr. Fadden, in 1939 and 1940, wherein it had been made abundantly clear that any government must use for the purpose of war finance and under exceptional conditions three sources of revenue, namely, taxation, voluntary loans, and central bank credit. .If we introduce compulsory loans, the receipts from them may be added to the returns from the voluntary loans. We have never said that we could finance war expenditure without the use of central bank credit. However, I desire the House to understand that every £100,000,000 which is added at this stage to the issue of central bank credit, reduces the amount that will be available to the Government in future for the prosecution of the war or for post-war reconstruction. By the end of June, 1944, this Government will have used in three years resources that would have financed the nation for five years.

talk.start.para: - Did not a former Treasurer, Mr. Casey, declare that in war-time the sky was the limit in regard to expenditure ?

- I cannot contradict the Minister, but I know Mr. Casey very well. As a representative' of New South Wales, I attended meetings of the Australian Loan Council at which he presided in his capacity as Commonwealth Treasurer. The 'statement attributed to him that in war-time the sky is the limit for expenditure should not be divorced from its context.

speech.para: I have advocated the liberal use of central bank credit for developmental purposes, and for providing works that would yield an income return to the country.

For those works, central bank credit of £5,000,000 or even £10,000,000 might be required, and the effects would be easy to control. But the issue of central bank credit to the amount of hundreds of millions of pounds can be justified for only one purpose, namely, the needs of the nation in war-time. No one will say that the nation shall not have every shilling that it requires for the conduct of the war. But the responsibility rests upon the Government to see that every possible opportunity is taken to reduce the issue of central bank credit, because some day, we may no longer be able to use this kind of finance. We have used central bank credit already far more than we should have done. We have brought ourselves closer by two years to the limit of finance than we needed to have done, because of the things which we have failed to do and which, if done, might have economized the use of our national resources.

talk.start.para: - Is there not a signpost to warn us that the limit has been reached ?

- The sign-post is clearly in sight to-day. The Government, by artificial controls, is endeavouring to conceal the existence of inflation and to a degree, it can do so. But the forces which will give rise to inflation are present. The moment these economic controls are removed, inflation will rear its ugly head. Even if the controls be not removed, the time will come when the pressure will blow off the lid.
- What is the limit?

- I myself have asked that question, and no one can give a satisfactory answer. My personal opinion is that the use .of central bank credit is related to many changing conditions. What would be a safe limit in one country might be unsafe in another, because of the conditions.
- In other words, it is a matter of opinion?
- No; that is a very easy way in which to shelve the question. The countries which have experienced inflation will deny that it is a matter of opinion.
- My opinion might be just as good as that of the honorable member.

- I do not desire to compete with the Minister, on the subject. I am prepared to admit at once that, his opinion is as good as mine. Nevertheless, this country is endangering its financial foundation and its future because of the issue of credit at the present rate, when a good deal of the danger could he avoided. I shall tell the House three things which the Government has failed to do, and which would have considerably reduced during the past eighteen months the very heavy issue of central hank credit. [Further extension of time granted.] The first point is that it failed, in the latter part of 1941, the whole of .1942, and up to the 31st March, 1943, to supplement revenue by additional taxation and postwar credits which, for eighteen months, would have brought a very large sum of money into the Treasury. I hesitate to estimate the amount, because such estimates are apt to be very unreliable, but I venture a guess that not less than £120,000,000 could have been so collected during those eighteen months.
- Where has that money gone ?
- It has been used by the public in other spending.
- Has it not been subscribed to war loans?
- Surely the Minister for War Organization of Industry does not believe that?
- I do.

- Then I decline to discuss the matter with him here. I do not accept his contention, nor, I am sure, will the Treasurer. The second point is the effect upon the price spiral of this failure to collect more revenue, an effect which now compels the Government in its day-to-day expenditure to pay very much more for war materials than would otherwise have been necessary. Everything which the Government buys, including materials for the making of munitions, and for the building of ships, &c, has been affected by the rise of prices, and this rise is due in no small measure to the factors which I have mentioned.

speech.para: The third point is one which justifies this challenge to the Government. There has undoubtedly been extravagance and lack of control in connexion with government expenditure. Again, I make no personal imputations. In financing a war, or carrying out any unusually large undertaking, there must always be a certain amount of waste, but there is a responsibility upon the Government to bring expenditure under control. I am not satisfied that the Government has done all it could in this regard. Had the Government acted differently in those three matters a great economy would have been possible in the use of central bank credit. Indeed, it is a conservative estimate which places the possible saving in this direction at one-half of the central bank credit issued up to the present time.

The danger to the nation's internal economy and to its industrial system caused by harsh regulations is very serious. These regulations are being crudely administered, in some instances by impractical theorists. The confusion is being added to by the financial factors to which I have already referred. I leave the matter at that.

This motion of want of confidence is entirely justified. The Government stands' charged with many breaches of sound administration which are having an injurious effect upon the war effort, and the spokesmen of the Government have failed to answer the charges.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member does not believe that.

- I do believe it. I have not touched upon the matter of industrial unrest; other speakers have addressed themselves to that. I have confined myself to a discussion of matters relating to financial administration. It is clear that the Government made a basic mistake in October, 1941, when it defeated the then Government on the budget, and when it said that there was need for a new financial plan. However, the Labour Government failed to follow any financial plan. From the time it assumed office there has been a drift in the nation's finances, leading to the difficulties which I have mentioned. Australia is only now beginning to feel the effects of this mistaken policy. I have no doubt that during 1943 and 1944 the country will suffer even- more severely. The Government must retrace its steps. Much damage has been done, but there is still time to avoid some of the worst effects of the Government's policy.

, - Many of the speakers in this debate have, as the Prime Minister (Mr. Curtin) pointed out, confined their remarks to purely domestic affairs, ignoring the paramount fact that Australia is at war, and that everything must be subordinated to that consideration. The Curtin Administration is ia office for the reason that the previous Government, of which the honorable member- for Robertson (Mr. Spooner) was a member, found itself unable to govern its own supporters, much less govern Australia. Therefore> the Labour party, witnessing the dissension in the ranks of government supporters^ and believing that the then Government was unable properly to continue the administration of the country, took steps, with the help of independent members, to turn out of office an administration which was imperilling the welfare of the country.

speech.para: The Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Fadden) referred briefly to finance, making some wide generalizations, but without defining the policy which he himself would apply if he had the opportunity, except that he again pinned his faith to the policy enunciated in his budget speech of 1941, with perhaps some extensions in certain directions. It is well to recall the position which existed before the present Government took office. War expenditure for the last year that the Menzies-Fadden Government was in office was estimated to be £170,000,000. This year war expenditure will, I believe, amount to £560,000,000. A small part of that might, possibly, represent wasteful expenditure, hut apart from that I should be glad to hear from members opposite how the present war expenditure is to be reduced. In the matter of war expenditure the Government is guided largely by its military advisers, who recommend what is necessary in order to provide for the safety of the country and to defeat the enemy. Indeed, it may be said that the Government's war policy is based on the recommendations of its military advisers and by its physical capacity to do the things recommended. All the allied nations have promised that everything that they can physically do to assist one another and the allied cause will be done. That being so, the question of the amount of money to be expended on the war effort becomes a secondary consideration. It is possible that some of the undertakings upon which the Government has embarked might have been carried out less expensively, or that closer supervision might have been exercised. The honorable member for Robertson said that, in the prosecution of any war, there must necessarily be some waste and extravagance, but in our case that could not conceivably amount to more than £10,000,000 or, at most, £20,000,000, a small sum when compared with the grand total of war expenditure.

We come back, therefore, to the question of how the money should be raised. War expenditure has increased from £170,000,000 to £560,000,000. It is safe to say that no honorable member of this House, not even the honorable member for Robertson, liberal-minded as he is, could have imagined at the beginning of the war that it would be possible to expend so much money and still maintain the economy of Australia in a stable condition. All would have said that it could not be done without plunging the country into a flood of inflation such as overwhelmed Germany in 1923. There may be differences of opinion as to how much money should be raised in addition to ordinary revenue in order to bridge the gap between income and expenditure, thus reducing the use of bank credit, but I am sure, that, if the honorable member for Robertson were Treasurer, he would not be prepared to say that the amount of money contributed by the public for the war effort could be greatly increased. If the press has reported correctly, the honorable member for Warringah (Mr. Spender) said some time ago that in his opinion taxation in this country had reached saturation point, and that very little was left to be obtained by that method. Let us examine the great scheme that was propounded by the Fadden Government in 1941. The honorable member for Robertson (Mr. Spooner) has said that, had it been adopted, the position to-day would have been much better. The honorable gentleman first claimed that prior to the introduction of this proposal, there had really been no financial policy in this country. The present occupants of the treasury bench were not responsible for that, because honorable members who now sit opposite had had control of the administration of the Commonwealth for a very long time prior to our advent to office. If there was no financial policy when Australia became involved in a great world war, previous, administrations were entirely responsible. What was the great policy which, in 1941, was to have changed completely the whole of the financial and economic position of this country? The Fadden Government proposed to raise £5,00;0,000 by means of taxation and £25,000,000 by means of post-war credits, a total of £30,000,000 at a time when the war expenditure was £200,000,000. That policy was brought down twenty months ago, in September, 1941. I can only assume that it was to have been the financial policy until at least the 30th June, 1942.

talk.start.para: - I do not agree with that. Japan came into the war two months later.

- I agree that the policy was announced prior to Japan's entry into the war. The budget to raise a total of £30,006,000 was brought down in September, 1941, midway between the end of the previous financial year and the end of the calendar year. That was the grand plan which the honorable member has said was to have saved this country from financial and economic chaos. It is perfectly true that he has also said that it would have been extended. The extension of it could only have meant the increase of post-war credits, upon the incidence of which one could speak for quite a long while. Japan entered the war at the end of 1941, and expenditure was tremendously accelerated. Let us compare with that particular plan what this Government has done for the purpose of obtaining finance to meet our war expenditure. The total increase of direct taxation alone has been £86,000,000. We proposed to raise, by means of indirect taxation, an amount of £29,000,000. There has been some reduction of that estimate, due to the falling off of goods and services on which indirect taxation is imposed. In 1940-41, the Fadden Government collected, by means of direct taxation, an amount of £50,000,000. At the rates that are being applied this year, an amount of £170,000,000 will be collected by that means, an increase of £120,000,000 compared with what the previous Govern- men proposed to raise for the purpose of financing the war. I agree with the honorable member for Robertson that the rate of expenditure had not then been accelerated as it has been since Japan entered the war. It is possible that the Fadden Government, as the honorable member has stated, would have revised its taxation rates or its post-war credits. The plain fact of the matter is, that the hardships temporarily imposed by post-war credits would have been as great as the payment of taxation; because, when this proposal was brought down, there was no promise in regard to the date of their repayment. I do not say that they would never have been repaid. When the last proposal was made by the Opposition, the probable date of repayment was specifically stated. The only difference of opinion that can exist is as to whether or not this Government has been sufficiently severe in its taxation of the public; whether it has secured the return to the Treasury of a sufficient percentage of the amount that has been distributed among the people. I have only to refer honorable members to the last bulletin issued by the Commonwealth Bank, in order to show that the taxation in Australia is heavier than the combination of taxation and post-war credits in most of the other countries that are engaged in the war.
- That has been the position only since the 1st April last.

- That is perfectly true. If honorable members opposite were immediately to become the occupants of the treasury bench, would they superimpose upon the taxation already in force in this country a system of postwar credits or additional taxation, notwithstanding the fact that the existing taxation is heavier than that of other countries ? If they did so, they would be asking the citizens of Australia to bear a greater taxation burden than the people of Britain and Canada are hearing on account of both taxation and postwar credits. It is true, as the honorable member for Robertson has said, that the existing taxation has been applied only since the beginning of last April. I take it, however, that that is the position which honorable members challenge when they say that something more could be done.

speech.para: Let us consider the submissions of the Leader of the Opposition in regard to the cost of living. The right honorable gentleman has stated that the cost of living has remained stationary in England since 1941. The truth of the matter is, that since the commencement of the war with Germany the cost of living in England has increased by 27-J per cent. It has not continued to increase since 1941, for the reason that the British Government has instituted a system of subsidies, which is now costing £200,000,000 per annum. I am very glad to have the opportunity of citing the Economist for the enlightenment of honorable members opposite, because they have lauded it as a fair judge of financial affairs. In its issue of the 16th January, 1943, it estimated, that, without subsidies by the Government, the cost of living in England would have increased by 40 per cent, since the outbreak of war. The cost of living regimen in England covers a very much narrower field than is covered by the " C " series index in Australia - which, I suppose, is one of the most comprehensive in the world, covering all those things that are regarded as necessary for the maintenance of a decent standard of living. Even on that narrow regimen, the cost of living in England has increased by 27£ per cent, since the outbreak of war; and, according to the Economist, it would have risen by 40 per cent, but for the payment of subsidies at the rate of £200,000,000 a year.

In considering the remarks of the honorable member for Robertson in connexion with the organization for war, I can hardly credit that he has not made an analysis of all the things that are necessary for the successful conduct of the war in the conditions under which we are fighting. Let us consider the position that confronted the present Government when it assumed office. The press has been quoted a great deal by the Leader of the Opposition, consequently I feel justified in quoting from it. If it has correctly stated the position, the office of War Organization of Industry, which the honorable member for Robertson filled for a time, was merely an empty shell. It has also stated that that was the opinion of the honorable member himself. When the present Government came into office, there was not in existence any control or direction of manpower. Certain dilution schemes had been introduced in the engineering trades, but there had not been any attempt to marshal the financial, economic or physical resources of this country for a total war effort. We were merely drifting along. There had been voluntary enlistments iia the Australian Imperial Force, and call-ups for militia training, but the number of men in the forces was not very large. The present Government had to undertake the task of fulfilling the promise which had been given to the

Allied nations that everything would be done of which this country was physically capable. It had so to organize the physical resources of Australia that the services of every man and woman, and every available material, would be diverted to purposes that were most conducive to ensuring that we were playing a total part in the Allied war effort.

Complaints have been made concerning the rationing of one commodity and the zoning of another. It was revealed that seven or eight milk, bread and butchers' carts were delivering in the one block every day of the week, employing labour and financial resources and materials. That state of affairs had to be altered. The best possible use had to be made of our available man-power and materials. Goods which, in the past, had been regarded as desirable though not absolutely essential had to be cut off from supply, because the raw materials were needed for the war effort. In twenty months, this Government has marshalled the resources of the country.

talk.start.para: - I hope that the Treasurer does not imply that the previous Government neglected to provide for the needs of war.
- The war had been in progress for a considerable time when this Government came into office.
- But Japan had not declared war.
- I do not wish to tell in full the interesting story that could be told on that subject.
- The Prime Minister (Mr. Curtin) said that excellent preparations had been made for the war, and that things were in a better condition than ever before.

- The Prime Minister admitted that in some directions, such, for example, as the designing and erection of munitions factories, good work had been done, and he paid a tribute of appreciation to those responsible for it.
- There is no reason why Ministers should not still be honest in that matter.
- I have n0 wish to rob previous governments of the credit that might be due to them in certain directions.
- In a good many instances proposed munitions factories had not been erected, and in others production had not commenced.

- That is true. Before Japan entered the war, and while the then Prime Minister, the right honorable member for Kooyong (Mr. Menzies), was abroad, the present Prime Minister, and the present Leader of the Opposition, and the present Minister for Supply and Shipping issued a joint statement in which they warned the country of the danger of war with Japan. The then Prime Minister, in press statements in Great Britain, attempted to make those honorable gentlemen look small by alleging that they had cried " wolf " without justification.
- What he said was nothing in comparison with what the present Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. Ward) said.

- That may be so, but there is a great difference between the information that is available to a Prime Minister, particularly when he is abroad and is in touch with the representatives of the United Kingdom and Allied Governments, and that, which is available to a private member. The honorable gentlemen who made the joint statement in this country at that time had sufficient sense to realize the imminence of war with Japan, and the then Prime Minister, who was in England, did himself no credit when he tried to ridicule them for so doing. The inference from the statements that he made was that war was not likely. War actually occurred shortly after this Government assumed office, with the result that it had to re-organize the affairs of the country. In that process it was inevitable that the interests of some people would be injured. It is not possible to change the conditions of living of a people accustomed to ease and luxury into conditions of war without inflicting some hardships. This Government undertook the task fearlessly. It marshalled our man-power and our raw materials in such a way as to ensure that non-essential industry would be discontinued and essential war industry expanded. In this respect I pay tribute to the Minister for War Organization of Industry (Mr. Dedman) for the work that was done. He, and those associated with him, undertook their task with relentless energy, even though some people advertised the fact that they were suffering hardship. Our raw materials were regimented and everything possible was done to increase our capacity to assist in the war effort of the Allied Nations, and to retain our own freedom. Naturally, some of the things that were done caused hostile criticism from the vested interests of the country, but the Government persevered in its policy.

speech.para: Some honorable gentlemen opposite have criticized the workers of this country and have spoken disparagingly of the action of certain Ministers, of whom I was one, who had attended trade union congresses. It has been said that fifteen Ministers were present at one meeting. I make no apology for that fact. The members of this Government are in office because of their long association with the trade union movement. I myself am here because of my association with trade unionism extending over 30 years. In endeavouring to frame a policy for the achievement of a maximum war effort, it was surely proper for the members of a Labour government to confer with the representatives of the workers' organizations in order to ensure that the best possible results would be achieved.

talk.start.para: - Every Labour Minister and every Labour government has done that kind of thing.

- The captains of industry in this country could not have provided the" needs of an army in the fe..1, nor could they have provided for an army in .the workshops, without the co-operation of the working classes. What was needed was not the distant and aloof attitude adopted by the right honorable member for Kooyong, but a close contact such as has been established by the members of this Government with those whom the right honorable member for Kooyong on one occasion referred to' as " the common people ". The honorable member for Robertson said a good deal about the flow of money and the pressure of price control and the like; but the Government had to take strong steps to regiment the nation for war. That could not be done without some interference with our economic and monetary system. I make no apology for having attended trade union congresses. Because trouble has occurred on the waterfront and among the miners of this country, some honorable gentlemen opposite have said -that undue industrial dislocation has disturbed the productive capacity of the nation. The fact of the matter is that apart from certain stoppages which have occurred in the two industries that I have mentioned, and in which not more than 20,000 have been involved, very little disturbance has occurred on the industrial front.
- Thirty thousand workers stopped work on one day.

- The honorable gentleman is referring to the dispute over Anzac Day. When I know that honorable members of this Parliament leave here every Friday afternoon to go to their homes where they can enjoy comfort, if not luxury, and I know that hundreds of thousands of workers in. this country have remained consistently in their employment, working day and night, and at the week-ends and on holidays, in the interests of the war effort, such carping criticism makes me sick at heart. Many miners have to go miles into the bowels of the earth to work under most unhealthy and unpleasant conditions. If they break the rules now and again it is not surprising ; but that is no reason for condemning all the workers of the country.

speech.para: Reverting for a moment to monetary questions, I frankly confess that this Government has had to take action in this sphere which had not been anticipated. As the result of the creation of bank credit, much money has flowed into the pockets of the working people, and their purchasing power has been greatly in excess of consumer-goods available. In the interests of the war effort the Government has had to prohibit the manufacture of many articles, and the goods available for purchase by the people have been continually reduced both in volume and in variety. I frankly admit that an excess of money flowing out to the people and a reduction of the supply of goods may create difficulties and, if not controlled, may lead to inflation, but the Government has applied controls which have greatly limited the tendencies in this direction. It has intensified price control and rationed many commodities for which the public would otherwise be competing. [Extension of time granted.] Such action has been taken fearlessly.

The honorable member for Warringah (Mr. Spender) wrote to me some time ago for particulars concerning war loans. I supplied some information to him, and although I did not inform him that it was confidential I regret to say that he used it in a broadcast in such a way as to suggest that the last war loan was a complete failure. That was not a fact. I point out that there were 422,000 individual subscribers to the last war loan, and that 90 per cent, of the subscriptions were for amounts of less than £100. The right honorable member for Warringah omitted to mention in his broadcast that, in addition to the number of individual subscribers, a large amount of the money subscribed by savings banks and insurance companies was provided by people of small means. Because only £10,000,000, or £11,000,000 was subscribed by people who contributed amounts of less than £100, it must not be inferred that that was the total sum obtained from such persons, for they contributed substantially through the savings banks in which they deposit their money.

talk.start.para: - The subscriptions of insurance companies also included a considerable amount of money by people of small means.

- That is true. I regret that the number of individual subscribers to the last loan was not greater, and I hope that a much larger number of individuals will subscribe to subsequent loans, but it is quite wrong to say that the loan was a failure.
- Sevenpence out of every1s. is going into war loans in these days.

- That is the position. Two loans were floated by the previous Government for a total of £64,000,000 with 80,000 subscribers, and with the help of the private banks. This Government floated three loans in 1941-42 for a total of £120,000,000 with 524,000 subscribers, and without the help of the trading banks. In 1942-43 we have floated two loans with 879,000 subscribers for a total of £184,000,000, also without the help of the private banks. What was the method of floating loans in this country before ? As a matter of fact, the honorable member for Warringah, when Treasurer, raised a loan in 1940 which had very few subscribers, because practically all of the money came from the banks. On all previous occasions other governments have allowed private banks to subscribe as much as they cared. This Government has not allowed the private banks to make a rake-off from public loans raised for the conduct of the war.
- But the Government is getting money from war-time deposits by the banks, free of interest.

- That money is not going into the loan. There is a total of over £103,000,000 in the war-time deposits by the private banks. If this Government had not been in office that money would have gone into the war loans, and the private banks would have got a rake-off during the war of from 21/2 to 31/4 per cent, in interest. As I say, one of the loans raised by a government representing the opposite side was purely a private bank loan. The Governments of the United States of America and Canada are using now the old system. In America, 35 per cent, of the money has come from the private trading banks.
- I did not encourage that policy.

- I do not think that the honorable member for Warringah has been a bosom friend of the private banks at any time. He was rather one of those who were responsible for seeing that they did not make an undue rake-off. The point I want to make, and that might well be put now, is that if the private banks had been allowed to subscribe to these loans the amount shown in treasury bills now could have been very considerably reduced. In other words we could have been paying to the private banks interest at the rate of from 21/2 to 31/4 per cent, on perhaps the whole £100,000,000 that is now lodged in war-time deposits with the Commonwealth Bank on which the interest is only .155 per cent. It is perfectly true that the treasury-bills now on issue to the Commonwealth Bank might at the same time have been reduced by £100,000,000 or some smaller sum, because the whole amount might not have been put into loans, but it cannot be denied that all other loan moneys raised by this Government have been obtained from the public without subscription by the trading banks.
- What is the Government paying the private banks on wartime deposits?
- The Commonwealth Bank is paying them 15s. per £100.
- What is the Government paying for treasury-bills?
- One and a half per cent.

- The Government is not saving the whole of the 21/2 or 31/4 per cent, that the banks would have got on war loans taken up by them, by holding their money in war-time deposits at 15s. per £100, or in treasury-bills at11/2 per cent.

- I am not saying that. My contention is that the gap of £200,000,000 or £260,000,000 of which the honorable member speakscould have been lessened by loans from the private banks to the amount of £100,000,000 if it had been the policy of the Government to allow those banks to make a rake-off from the excess of deposits coming over their counters as the result of government activities.
- But that is the policy which the Fadden Government instituted. It was in the budget before the Curtin Government came into power.
- Where is it on record ?
- In the budget statement.

- The two loans floated in 1940-41 prior to this Government taking office were both raised with the help of the private banks. They brought in £64,000,000 from 80,000 subscribers. A considerable portion of the money was found by the private trading banks, and that has been the policy of the party on the other side of the House whenever it has been in office. It is perfectly true, as the honorable member for Robertson has said, that the Fadden Government thought about a repentance, but it was a deathbed repentance.

speech.para: What I wish to make perfectly clear is that in the eighteen or twenty months that this Government has been in office the economy of this country has been managed, in my opinion, at least as well as that of any other country in the world. The cost of living in this country has increased by 22-J per cent, since the war broke out. The increase in the United Kingdom has been 27-J per cent, despite the use of subsidies at the rate of £200,000,000 per year.

talk.start.para: - I do not think the Treasurer would like to tell the housekeeper that the cost of her food and clothing has risen by only 22£ per cent. That is an overall figure which includes a lot of things in which there has been no increase.

- I am taking the Statistician's figures, because I am told by economists that if the real figures were given in Great Britain, apart from subsidies and not on such a limited regimen, it would be found that the cost of living had gone up by 40 per cent. I do not need to remind the honorable member that the " O " series index adopted by th Commonwealth Arbitration Court to determine the cost of living is the most complete in the world. Whatever defect there may be in other systems, there is evidence that this index is a true reflex of the cost of living.
- But it includes a number of things like rents, in which there has been no increase since the war began.
- There has been no increase in rents because the Government took steps to peg them.

- I am not saying that the 22-J per cent, is a fictitious increase, but in fact the real increase is very much more. I do not say that that is the Government's fault but it does include many things which have not increased at all ; it is an overall figure.

- That is quite a different case from the figures put before the courts by the employers. They say that it is an almost flawless system. I do not admit that, because I have had some personal experience of the courts.

- I admit that it is very hard to get another system. I do not say that the present one is bad, but when the Treasurer takes that figure he must realize the incidence of it. I probably would be obliged to adopt some similar system. I do not see how it could be avoided.

- I believe that the economy of this country has been managed equally as well as, if not better than, any other economy in the world. The Government does realize the .inflationary tendencies associated with the increase in the flow of bank credit, in conjunction with diminishing quantities of goods available for purchase. I do not pretend that either the number or the amount of the contributions from voluntary loans is all that we would desire. I can only say that both are far in excess of any anticipations which might have been made a few years ago. The numbers are greater, and the amounts are greater. It may be that, as time marches on, the economic control will have to be tightened still more, and that as regards many of the things now controlled by what the honorable member for Robertson described as harsh and tyrannical regulations, the controls may have to be tightened still further if we are to make a complete and final effort in this war, especially if the war should continue for any length of time. It is possible that they may be used by members of the Opposition to win a few votes here and there. I even noticed that the honorable member for Robertson a few weeks ago was bemoaning the imposition of raceless Saturdays. I assume that he has a racing club in his electorate.
- But it is rather ridiculous, is it not, to stop races on one Saturday and allow them on four others ?
- Nothing could be more ridiculous than the honorable member's argument.
- If the Government thinks that racing should be stopped to increase the war effort, why does it not stop all racing?

- It is safe to say that the honorable member's recent protest was the first thought he' ever gave to racing. Probably he said, " Here is a body of people, consisting of a few bookmakers and others, associated with racing around Gosf ord ".
- The Treasurer has no more proof of that than of his assertion that Australia's economy is the best managed in the world. I do not think he could prove that statement.

- I do not impute impure motives to the honorable member, but there are those who, because some retriction has had to be applied in order to produce a total war effort, and a few votes and a little sympathy can be won by making an appeal to the emotions of the people concerned, are prepared to take such action for political purposes. [Further extension of time granted.] It may be true that it is the way of politicians to take advantage of the difficulties in which the Government finds itself, but the position that we are taking up and will continue to take up is that if something has to be done for the purpose of adding to the total war effort in which we are engaged, this Government will do it irrespective of whether it is popular or unpopular. That has been the policy of the Government for the twenty months that it has been in office. As to whether more money can be obtained from the public in various ways, my personal opinion is that, except perhaps for some adjustments in certain cases, taxation has reached its limit at the present time. If the honorable member for Robertson and the Leader of the Opposition are prepared to go out and tell the people that they will increase it or create post-war credits on the present heavy scale of taxation they are welcome to make the attempt. If the members of the Opposition believe that it ought to be done, and can show a way of doing it, and are prepared to make it an election placard, they are quite welcome to do so, but, in my opinion, if post-war credits are instituted, what is now a very valuable source of voluntary loans will be dried up. No matter how effective the Opposition may believe that taxation or post-war credits can be made, our system is getting from everybody all that can be given by way of voluntary loans. No system of postwar credits or taxation can he applied fairly over the whole community. There are always some people upon whom an undue burden is placed, but there are others who, after meeting their commitments, are still able to contribute to voluntary loans, and it is that factor which makes it so desirable that our voluntary loan system should continue. This Government has no intention to introduce a scheme of post-war credits, whatever circumstances may arise. That has been made perfectly clear. "We believe that the money that is available in the community can best be obtained by means of taxation. That has always been the policy of this Government, and I think that I speak for my colleagues when I say that it will continue to be our policy. I agree with the honorable member for Warringah that direct taxation has nearly reached saturation point, and I do not deny for one moment that the burdens which this Government has been obliged to place upon the community rest more heavily upon some individuals than upon others. It is not possible to apply taxation over the entire community with equal incidence, having regard to the personal commitments of each individual. In the course of hi3 speech yesterday, the Leader of the Opposition said - . . if financial policy is not drastically changed, we shall find ourselves after the war with a completely totalitarian economy without any possibility of its liberalization.

speech.para: Just what in the name of heaven that has to do with the question of finance, I do not know. The right honorable gentleman went on to say -

quote.para: It will be to the everlasting shame and economic detriment of Australia if a halt is not called before too late.

speech.para: I invite honorable members opposite to place before this House the proposal that they have in mind to remedy the situation. I am confident that they could not propose anything that has not been contemplated already by this Government. People such as Lord Keynes in England talk a great deal about preventing the upward pressure on prices by means of post-war credits, but they have not been able to achieve that objective. No country engaged in this war has been able to meet its expenditure solely by taxation and loans, and bank credits have had to be resorted to. The only question at issue is how much or how little it is advisable to take by this method. Surely no one would suggest for a moment that essential war expenditure should be reduced by one penny merely because it was likely to increase the amount of bank credit required. The important thing is that there should be complete control of bank credit when it flows out to the public. Of course, there will he abuses such as black marketing; but there is black marketing in every country in the world, even in Germany, where the most rigid and tyrannical regulations to suppress it are in force. Black marketing will always exist so long as there is a shortage of goods for which people have the money to pay. If the honorable member for Robertson believes that it is possible to control the economy of this country and to prevent the upward pressure upon prices merely by adopting post-war credits or by increasing taxation, he is only deluding himself.

talk.start.para: - I said that I did not think that could be done.

- The only question that this Government has to answer is, has it done its best under the worst possible circumstances, at a time when a tremendous strain has been placed upon the economy of this country ? I venture to say that many people who not very long ago were talking about inflation, were doing so in a manner not likely to be of assistance to this country. There was a great deal of such talk, but it has ceased since the loan was subscribed. Apparently some individuals had the idea that the loan would be a failure, and that there would be some justification for talk of inflation. Certain South Australian members of this Parliament made statements in regard to the loan which were a disgrace to them. I refer to the honor able member for Boothby (Dr. Price) and certain honorable senators.
- But the Treasurer will admit that most members of the Opposition did all in their power to assist that loan.

- That is so. I have no wish to deny credit to honorable members opposite generally for the work that they did at that time, but it cannot be denied that certain other honorable gentlemen made statements calculated to damage the prospects of success of that loan. One can only infer from the remarks made by these honorable gentlemen that they would have derived some degree of pleasure had the loan failed.

speech.para: In conclusion, I say emphatically, that no matter what sum of money is obtained by way of taxation or post-war credits, whatever Government is in office will find itself obliged to appeal to the people of this country for voluntary loans.

talk.start.para: . - I support the motion of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Fadden). I say without hesitation that because of its actions, the Government deserves to lose not only the confidence of this House, but also the confidence of the people. Honorable members opposite are endeavouring, under the cloak of war-time measures, to force the policy of the party to which they belong, upon this country. They are attempting to proceed with the socialization of industry, and to force compulsory unionism upon the people although clearly they do not favour preference to returned soldiers. Proof of that is to be found in the treatment that has been meted out to a woman employee of a certain industrial organization in Sydney. That case is only typical of many. I have here a telegram from Parkes stating -

quote.para: Mrs. Humfrey whose husband is a prisoner of war in Borneo has worked in local important undertakings for five weeks. Consistently worried by officials demanding that she join union. Given time limit and ultimatum by union president yesterday. Manager agreed no alternative but to join or seek release. Union president stated Australia-wide strike likely over Mrs. Cassidy. Under extreme pressure Mrs. Humfrey agreed to seek release which action described as unpatriotic by union president Preston.

item.label: A.
item.para: M. Balcombe.

item.label: G.
item.para: B. Downes.

speech.para: If we permit the present drift to continue, we shall soon see established in this country, a set of conditions similar to those existing in the Axis countries. It is deplorable that union officials should be allowed to refer to women working in our war effort as "slimy toads " and that an unfrocked skunk such as Jock Garden should be permitted to threaten to put women to work "up to their necks in dirt ".

talk.start.para: - Mr. Garden denied that he had made such a statement.

- I would prefer to accept the word of a woman like Mrs. Cassidy than that of Jock Garden. I know Jock Garden's record, and it is such that no sensible man would believe him. The Prime Minister (Mr. Curtin) said that compulsory unionism was not a part of the Government's policy; but I point out that when a man seeks employment in a government munitions factory the first question that he is asked is " Are you a member of a union ? " If the answer is in the negative, he is informed that there is no possibility of obtaining work unless he joins a union.
- That question was asked in the government munitions factories before the Labour Government assumed office.

- Many prospective employees of these establishments are opposed to unionism and are accepting munitions work because they realize the importance of maintaining a flow of arms and equipment to our fighting forces ; yet they are obliged to subscribe to unions and so to assist the payment of salaries to union officials of whose activities they do not approve. I know of a man in Bendigo who was put out of work because of the order given by this Government that all gold-mining was to cease. He was an engine-driver, and as engine-drivers were required for war work, he applied for work at a munitions factory and was asked if he belonged to the Engine Drivers and Firemen's Union. He did not, for the simple reason that some years previously there had been a strike in the mines at Bendigo, and realizing the tremendous damage that would be done to the mines if water were allowed to flow into them, he and about ten others did not join the strikers. However, he was prepared to join the union, and went to the local Trades Hall for that purpose, but they would not accept him. He then went to the Trades Hall in Melbourne, but still his application for membership was refused ; yet in the Trades Hall in Bendigo there is a board, like an honour roll of the men who fell in the Great "War, bearing the names of those engine-drivers who were loyal to their employers and their industry, and underneath them the inscription " Lest we forget ". Such action is an insult to the soldiers who fought and died for this country. That is the reason why he cannot get work to-day, even though engine-drivers are urgently required. Although the man to whom I have referred is a good citizen, he is prevented by these apostles of peace and fair dealing from earning a livelihood.

speech.para: The Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. Ward) made many wild statements in his speech. For instance, he declared, although he had no knowledge of the facts, that an aerodrome was constructed at Tocumwal as a part of the defensive arrangements in connexion with " the Brisbane line ". Aerodromes were constructed throughout the country for defence purposes.

talk.start.para: - What does the honorable member know about defence?
- I was prepared to offer my life for the purpose of defending this country, but the Minister has described our troops as " six-bob-a-day murderers ".
- We do not collect two salaries in the name of patriotism.
- Nearly every member of the Labour party is collecting, in addition to his parliamentary allowance, special allowances for serving on various parliamentary committees,
- I deny that.

- The Minister for Labour and National Service omitted to mention the details regarding the construction of a costly aerodrome at Maryborough, in Victoria. That aerodrome has never been used, and residents of the district explain that the work was undertaken by mistake, because the site for. the aerodrome was Maryborough, in Queensland. The Minister also declared that Australian airmen sought to resist the first aerial onslaught of the Japanese in "Wirraways because we had no modern fighter aircraft. There is a perfectly reasonable explanation. The Battle of Britain was being fought, and British cities were being battered day after day. Every modern fighter available was required to defend them. In addition, Australian troops were fighting in Libya, Greece and Crete without adequate aerial protection. In the evacuation of Crete, British warships were so mercilessly bombed by German aircraft that only by a miracle were they able to reach Alexandria. If Australia had insisted upon fighter aircraft being sent to this country while the nearest enemy was in Libya, the light aerial screen then, available in the Middle East would have been further weakened.

speech.para: The Labour party opposed the despatch of the Australian Imperial Force abroad. The Government "Whip (Mr. Conelan), denied that he had voted against the decision of the Menzies Government to send an expeditionary force overseas, but Hansard, of the 29th November, 1939, page 17-65, discloses his name in a division list as opposing it. If the Australian Imperial Force had not been sent to North Africa, we would have been defeated in that area. Mr. Churchill told Major-General Morshead : " Your 9th Division has again stopped the enemy". If it had not been for Australian troops, the Axis would have overrun Egypt and invaded Syria. Such a victory would have had a tremendous effect on the people of India, and the Arab population of Asia and Africa. Egypt and Suez were just as much the gateway to Australia as Singapore was, and we know all too well what happened when that bastion fell.

talk.start.para: - 'What did the United Australia party- do about it?

- If it had not been for the previous Government, no defence of Australia would have been possible when Japan broke through the outer bastion. The Labour party was totally opposed to any form of defence.
- That is not correct.
- I shall prove it. Hansard discloses that the Minister for Labour and National Service stated -

quote.para: It is amusing to hear people say that we shall not give up New Guinea - to those people

I would say that if it should become necessary to defend our mandated territory they should defend it themselves. As far as I am concerned, all I can judge about the necessity for retaining New Guinea is that a handful of exploiters have got hold of the country, some interested in aerial transport, some in gold-mining, and some in the search for oil. These people want to retain New Guinea in order to preserve their own commercial interests.

speech.para: If we had adopted the policy advocated by the Minister, New Guinea would have been left defenceless.

talk.start.para: - The United Australia party Government left it defenceless.
- The Prime Minister declared that Port Moresby was the last bastion between the Japanese and Australia.
- "What did the honorable member do about it?

- The honorable member for Hunter (Mr. James) reminds me of a story. "When walking down a street, a man overtook a lady and spoke to her. She asked him haughtily what he wanted, and he replied. " I thought you were my mother ". She answered, " Excuse me, I am married ".

speech.para: The Minister for War Organization of Industry (Mr. Dedman), stated recently that no attempt had been made to place industry on a war-time footing until he took charge of the department. After Australia had been at war for two years, he stated -

quote.para: I should not have risen at this late hour but for a matter which I consider to be of supreme importance. Certain constituents of mine, members of the Militia Force, have received notice that they will be required for continuous military duty for the duration of the war. I have not made any bones about where I stand in regard to conscription. I am opposed to conscription for home service as well as for service overseas. I am opposed to it on religious grounds, because I do not believe that any man or any government ought to force any individual to take up the art of killing his fellow-men.

talk.start.para: - The Minister for War Organization of Industry is a returned soldier. Was he not entitled to express his opinion?
- He expressed the views of the Labour party.
- What is wrong with that?

- The Prime Minister accused the Opposition of being defeatist in outlook. Could anything be more defeatist than the statement of the Minister ? The Prime Minister disclosed that when the Labour Government took office, Australia had only 60 per cent, of the number of rifles required to defend this country. The explanation is that when France surrendered, Britain which was defeated at Dunkirk, was left practically unarmed, and Australia sent 40,000 rifles, although we required them for our own troops, to assist in the defence of the Motherland. Even the most innocent honorable member opposite will not contend that Australia could have carried on the war if Britain had been defeated. Not only would we have been defeated as an empire, but the war as a whole would have been lost throughout the world for the freedom-loving nations, and Nazi-ism would have triumphed. The Minister for Labour and National Service said that the right honorable member for Kooyong (Mr. Menzies) was responsible for the sending of scrap iron to Japan. It is true that some scrap iron was sent to Japan from Australia, and it is also true that a very large quantity was sent from the United States of America. In return for the iron which we sent, we received from Japan machine tools which are being used in our war. effort to-day. I remind honorable members opposite that a very short time before war was declared practically every Labour representative in Western Australia objected bitterly to the fact that the Menzies Government refused to allow the Japanese to develop the Yampi .Sound iron ore deposits. The Government was charged with acting out of the desire to protect the " interests of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company Limited. If the Japanese had been allowed to establish themselves at Yampi Sound, to take possession of the harbour there, and to obtain unlimited quantities of iron ore, we would not be a free people to-day. The then Premier of Western Australia protested very strongly against the action of the Commonwealth Government in stopping that deal. Just before war broke out, the honorable member for Wimmera (Mr. Wilson) wanted us to enter into an arrangement to sell wheat to Japan on long-term credit, and when his proposal was declined, he said we were being too hard on Japan. He wanted us to sell them wheat so that they might feed themselves up in .readiness to fight us.

speech.para: The Minister for Labour and National Service blamed the Bruce-Page Government for selling the Australian Commonwealth Line of Steamers. The fact is that the ships were sold because there was so much industrial trouble among the seamen that it was impossible for the line to carry on. There was strike after strike. Tremendous losses were incurred, the men going out on the slightest pretext. The Minister also said that we should socialize the coal industry in order to stop strikes. I point out that the mine owned by the Government of New South Wales is one of the worst in that State so far as strikes are concerned.

talk.start.para: - You are a liar !
- Is the honorable member iti order in making that statement ?
- What is the remark complained of?
- The honorable member said that I was a liar.
- So you are.
- The honorable member for Hunter (Mr. James) mustwithdraw his remark and apologize immediately.
- Out of respect to you, Mr. Speaker, I withdraw the remark and apologize, but the honorable member made a wilful and deliberate misstatement.
- The honorable member must withdraw his statement without any qualifications.
- I withdraw the remark without any ' qualifications, but reserve my opinion to express it outside.

- There have been innumerable strikes in the coal-mining industry. There may be one or two mines with a greater record of strikes than the State coal-mine, but then the coal industry in New South Wales is mainly noted for the number of strikes which have taken place in war-time. Recently, there was what was called the butter strike on the coal-field. The men struck because their own Government brought in a regulation rationing butter so that Ave .might be able to supply to the Mother Country the butter so urgently needed by the men working in the coal-mines there, by those in the munitions factories and in the armed forces, including our own Australians serving in the Air Force. The miners cannot blame the employer for the fact that butter has been rationed. That is a matter between them and the Governin ent.

speech.para: The Minister for Supply and Shipping (Mr. Beasley) made the statement - astounding to any man who has had experience of war - that the Australian Imperial Force was not suitable for jungle warfare because the men had been trained for desert fighting. He appealed to me to confirm his statement, and I said that it was utter rot. There is only one place where men can gain battle experience, and that is in the field against the enemy. Whether men fight in trenches, as we did in Gallipoli, or on the sands of North Africa, they gain battle experience. They learn discipline. They are toughened, so that they are able to stand the rigours of a campaign. Any man who has had battle experience, if he is a soldier at all, can adapt himself to varying conditions. By sending men to the Atherton Tableland they may receive training to make them more fit to fight under conditions similar to those in New Guinea. Their efficiency will be increased in that way, but nothing could so contribute to their fighting efficiency as the battle experience they gained in North Africa. There they covered themselves with glory, and helped to save Australia just as surely as did the mcn who fought in New Guinea. Australians who served on Gallipoli afterwards went to France and to the Sinai Peninsula, and in the Light Horse proved themselves at Romani under desert conditions, and later in the mountains and snows of Syria. They showed that they were able to adapt themselves to an entirely new set of conditions. It is laughable to hear the Minister for Supply and Shipping say that members of the Australian Imperial Force were not suitable for jungle fighting. This comes well from a man who knows nothing of war, a man who, like the Minister for Labour and National
Service, took fine care that he never had an opportunity to become battle-wise.

I object to the attempt of the Prime Minister to use the name of General Douglas MacArthur for political purposes. [Extension of time granted.] Every decent person in Australia must be disgusted at such an attempt. The Labour Government claims that it brought General Douglas MacArthur to Australia, but this claim is refuted by the following statement published in the Brisbane Courier-Mail of the 19th March, 1942 :-

quote.para: Not even the Australian Prime Minister, Mr. Curtin, knew that General MacArthur was actually on his way to Australia. News of his arrival in Australia was conveyed to Mr. Curtin in a dramatic message from President Roosevelt, presented to Mr. Curtin by Lieut-General Brett on Tuesday. The President suggested that ' it would bo highly acceptable to him and pleasing to the American people for the Australian Government to nominate General MacArthur as supreme commander of all the Allied Forces in the South West Pacific.' The President regretted "that he was unable to inform Mr. Curtin of General MacArthur's pending arrival.'

speech.para: The newspapers which support the Government are publishing pictures of Mr. Curtin meeting General Douglas MacArthur, who is reported to be remarking, " It is good to meet you, John ". As a matter of fact, we know that this is all merely election propaganda. The Government is trying to use this man, with his great record, to boost itself in the eyes of the public - and it will need a lot of boosting. The people of Australia are awake to the fact that the Government is trying to force the Labour party's policy down their throats on the pretext of war necessity. It is making use of Australia's difficult position in order to socialize industry, knowing that it has no mandate from the people to do so, and is unlikely to receive one.

The" Government has undoubtedly fallen down on its job in the way it has handled strikes. The soldiers, who are fighting in defence of Australia, will not tamely accept the present situation. They are bitter at the failure of the Government to deal with strikers. They resent the fact that members of the 9th Division were recalled from their leave and put to work on the Sydney wharfs while the waterside workers who should have been loading and unloading the ships were content to he merely onlookers. They criticize the employment of these men at this work for 6s. 6d. a day and the payment into Consolidated Revenue of the extra amount received from the shipping companies, when the wage rate for waterside workers is Ss. and 9s. an hour. 'Condemnation of strikers at home is contained in a letter that was written recently by a New Guinea soldier to relatives in Victoria. The letter has been forwarded to the Army, officers of which say that it is typical of the opinion of the fighting soldiers of some phases of Australia's -\var effort. The letter reads, inter alia -

quote.para: Will you tell Celie that whilst she and her colleagues arc struggling, men fighting up here need ammunition? Ask her to say just how she would act if we were to go on strike because we are not getting as much money as munition workers? It is not time to think of money-making, but time that all did something towards running this damn war.

How I wish some strikers knew what it was like to hear the scream of a falling bomb, to wonder where it was going to land. If only they could be up here for one night to hear the warning go, to dive into a funk-hole halffilled with water, and wait, afraid, knowing full well that in ten minutes they would be overhead and hell let loose. That is something you don't read about, in the papers, because the papers allow for the average intelligence being such that a man or woman can see or think far enough ahead to know just what would happen should the enemy strike at their home.

speech.para: Not only are these men dissatisfied with the attitude of the Government towards strikes, but also the men of the 9th Division are disgruntled because they were withdrawn from the great international force which smashed the Axis armies in North Africa. The men who broke through at El Alamein were brought home and robbed of the fruits of their courage and the victories they had achieved, whilst the division of our sister dominion was left in North Africa to continue the fight with British, American, French, Indian and Polish troops. Although they were glad to see their own country, and to rejoin those who were near and dear to them, they are discontented at having been withdrawn from that theatre of war and thus robbed of their share of the victory that was subsequently won. They say in no uncertain language that they object to having been brought back by a craven Government. That is the view, not of one or two men, but of hundreds of officers, non-commissioned officers and the rank and file.

talk.start.para: - The honorable gentleman is deluding himself.

- I am not. I have been asked by an honorable member whether I ever read Smith's Weekly. There has been a lot of discussion concerning " the Brisbane line ", which has been described as " the Brisbane lie ". Those who have related the story, and have endeavoured to foist on to a previous Government the responsibility for the existence of the state of affairs depicted, know that they lie. The honorable member for Hunter has endeavoured to infer that General Sir Iven Mackay, a gallant soldier who fought with distinction in two wars for this country and the Empire, was used by previous governments. He ought to be ashamed of himself for having cast a reflection on such a distinguished record.
- I said last night that I did not reflect on General Mackay.

- The honorable gentleman may imagine that he did not, but that is the inference which every honorable member drew from his remarks. I quote the following from Smith's Weekly of the 19th June last : -

quote.para: Mr. Frank Forde has always been to us a burlesque iii political propitiation. He's a museum' specimen.
Born to be all things to all men, he spends more time doing nothing than do even the lilies of the field. His amiability, however, is vociferous.

Never was there in our public life anyone so vocal in goodwill. The milk of human kindness fairly oozes from his benign countenance. It would not be polite to describe him as oleaginous. Let it merely be said that he is a convincing well-wisher and is always prepared to look into anything on behalf of anyone. We see him for ever looking into things earnestly, even if the results are never visible. (He was going to look into canteen accounts, for example).

Anything more comforting than to be a voter in Capricornia it is hard to imagine. To know that Mr. Forde kept watch and ward over us would bc an immeasurable solace. Since 1922 he has bestowed this benediction upon the people who live under the Goat Stars, after which his electorate is so happily named.

speech.para: The Minister for the Army owns a very stately home which is a- long way south of the so-called Brisbane line. He pays visits to units, garbed in warlike clothes which I suggest he is donning about 30 years too late.

The Government has failed to do the job which should be done in war-time. It has forfeited the confidence of this House, the people of this country, and the members of the fighting forces. I believe that when judgment has been pronounced upon it by the electors, who are its masters, there will be many gaps in its ranks. That will be for the good of this country and its people, including our fighting forces. I hope that a sober, sensible, trustworthy government will be given the opportunity to repatriate our fighting men when the war is over, and see that they receive preference in employment, and ensure that the whole of the people will have reasonable living conditions, with the result that Australia will have the opportunity to become the great nation that it ought to be.

talk.start.para: . - I was amused at the reference of the honorable member for Bendigo (Mr. Rankin) to the position in New Guinea. A commanding officer in that area, broadcasting over the national network, made the following interesting statement: -

quote.para: As one who has been for two years in the Middle East, I say that the soldiers who came back from that theatre of war, despite the fact that they had had more training, knew no more about New Guinea warfare than did the men who went from the Commonwealth.

speech.para: The honorable member for Bendigo reveals by his statements that he has no knowledge of jungle conditions. I admit quite candidly that a man who has not had experience in warfare cannot be as good as one who has. That is true in every walk of life. But men who were trained in jungle warfare in the electorates of the honorable member for Kennedy and myself, would lack only actual battle experience; they would be acquainted with every other condition that they would be likely to encounter. In saying this, I am not relating a fairy tale.

talk.start.para: - The men who returned from the Middle East had had actual battle experience.
- I appreciate that. But battle experience has very little value if one cannot detect the presence of an enemy three or four yards distant.

speech.para: The Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Eadden) ha3 said a good deal about food production. He has claimed that when he was the head of the Government of this country the position in relation to food was sound and that supplies were plentiful. That cannot be denied. When he was Prime Minister, his Government had. not to deal with the problems which confront the present administration. There was not then in Australia the enormous number of Americans that is here to-day. I do not think that any one regrets their presence. But they would not have been here but for John Curtin. He received from the President of the United States of America an understanding that General Douglas MacArthur would be sent to Australia to take charge of the South- West Pacific Area. The date of the General's arrival would not be known to either the President or the Prime Minister. He was accompanied by other Americans, and subsequently large numbers of forces, both men and women, arrived in this country. We have to provide the food that they eat. With our depleted man-power, that task has made it more difficult for the Government to maintain the position that -previously existed.

I do not intend to concern myself with the statements that have been made in connexion with what is termed "the Brisbane line". I shall not say that there was no organization of any kind when the present Government assumed office.
