But I cannot allow to pass without comment the assertions of the ex-Minister for Air, the honorable member for Indi (Mr. McEwen), in regard to the number of aerodromes that had been established. In the electorate that I represent there were aerodromes, if they can be so described, on which even a small Douglas machine could not land and from which it could not take off. Aeroplanes were compelled to pass daily over a number of towns because of the lack of accommodation on the aerodromes and the shortness of the runways. Those conditions have since been altered. I know the feelings of the people in regard to the position that existed a little over a year ago.

During the last twelve months, I have visited North Queensland on three occasions; consequently, I am competent to speak of the manner in which the conditions in that area have been altered. The honorable member for Kennedy (Mr. Riordan), who unfortunately is laid aside with influenza, can verify what I say in regard to the improvement of the position.

Comment has been made concerning evacuations from certain districts. One would imagine that the people of North Queensland had run away in order to escape trouble. Some of them may have done so, but they do not belong to the working class. Many working men in that area sold their furniture in order to obtain money to remove their wives and children to safety. That was done because the police and national emergency service officers conducted house to house visitations and asked such questions as: " Are you prepared to evacuate if necessary ? ", " How many are in this house ? ", and so on. 'Such inquiries were calculated to create an evacuation complex. I know of individuals who told householders that if they were able to get out of the district, they would not remain there for 48 hours. Naturally, in such circumstances, the local residents considered that a Japanese attack was imminent and they did their utmost to remove their wives and families. To-day, they are trying to get back to their homes and properties, for conditions have entirely altered. To-day, aerodromes and airstrips run from Woodstock right through to the coast and through Mount Isa and Cloncurry to Darwin. These would not have been there except for the work of the ground staff of both the Australian and American armies, who have done a wonderful job. Many farmers in my electorate voluntarily left their farms, taking their tractors with them, in order to engage in essential defence work. Over some periods they worked for 24 hours a day in three shifts.

I do not consider that General Douglas MacArthur would ever have come to Australia except for the appeal made by John Curtin. Yet, when that appeal was made, honorable gentlemen opposite said that we were " squealing " for help and wanted to cut the painter. I have never heard such rubbish. A good deal has been said in this debate about the wisdom or otherwise of sending the Australian Imperial Force abroad. I voted against that policy and I would do so again, notwithstanding all that has been said about the wonderful battle experience that our men have gained. The Prime Minister, who was responsible for sending the Australian Imperial Force abroad was supposed to have adopted the Chamberlain policy, but Mr. Chamberlain did not ask for men from the Dominions. He wanted equipment, foodstuffs and munitions generally. I do not think that that statement can be truthfully denied. He also stated that if an enemy landed on Australian soil the British Government would do its utmost to send help to within two or three months. As a matter of fact, it could not have done so. I do not in any sense disparage the Government of the United Kingdom. I appreciate that it has done a wonderful job in providing for the defence of its own territory and the protection of the British people against very great odds. Of course, that was its first responsibility.

When the Curtin Government came into office it had to face a desperate state of affairs. The previous Government had been completely ineffective; so much so, that the honorable member for Henty (Mr. Coles) told us that he would not continue to support it because he did not think it was possible for a competent government to be formed from the members of the non-Labour parties as they included too many would-be Prime Ministers. We have been told that the country is short of this, that and the other commodity and that man-power is a great difficulty. I believe that every intelligent person in the community appreciates that fact. We all know that industry has suffered. About three-fifths of the sugar produced in Australia comes from my electorate. I have watched the development of this industry ever since I started work as an organizer for the Sugar Workers Union 36 years ago. Although I have not a shilling invested in the industry, I know something of the sacrifices that the sugar-growers have made. Before the war, this was probably ' the most efficiently conducted sugar industry in the world, although it was said at one period that white men would not be able to do the work necessary to. grow sugar; but the industry is languishing to-day because of the lack of man-power and fertilizers. Cane tonnage in some parts of my district will be reduced by 50 per cent, this year as against last -year, due to the fact that many suger-farmers have left the area in order to engage in essential work for the Civil Constructional Corps. They volunteered for this important duty because they realized the plight of the country. There will also be a serious reduction of the sugar content of the cane.

I have been striving in this House for a long time for an improvement of the conditions of internees. After these individuals have succeeded in appeals to the alien appeal tribunals they are kept in the south doing so-called national work. I consider that after obtaining release following a successful appeal, they should he allowed to return to their wives and families to take up the work of food production which is so important. While they are in the south they rarely do any effective work. I agree with the statement made by one honorable member to-day that some persons are behind barbed wire in Australia who should be free and others, some of whom are not far from me, should be placed behind barbed wire in the interests of the general community.

There is a good deal of talk to-day about strikes and absenteeism in industry. The Leader of the Opposition read half of a statement made by Mr. Colin Clark, of Queensland, to the effect that 30 per cent, of the absenteeism was due to the failure of women workers to attend various establishments in which they are employed. If the right honorable gentleman had been fair, he would have said that Mr. Colin Clark had also stated that many of these persons were married women with families, and that they absented themselves from work on occasions not because they desired to do so, but because it was necessary for them to do the shopping that was essential for the maintenance of their children. I am glad that an attempt is being made to find a solution of this difficulty. I regret that strikes occur in industry. For very many years I have regarded strikes as a bad proposition for the workers, who rarely get anything worth while out of striking.

A good deal has also been said about compulsory unionism by honorable members who have participated in the debate but who know very little about compulsory unionism. The honorable member for Bendigo (Mr. Rankin) made some disgraceful statements on this subject. I do not believe that he knows the first thing about unionism, and from the views that he has expressed I do not consider that he would ever join a trade union. Preference to unionists is the settled policy in Queensland industries, and has been so for many years, and there are fewer industrial troubles in that State than in any other State. In Queensland there is more conciliation and less arbitration than in other States. The arbitration judge only goes on the bench when it is necessary for him to deal with a point of law. Generally, conciliatory methods are applied to industrial disputes. We hear very little about stoppages of work in the coalmining industry of Queensland. It is usually the coal-miners of New South Wales who are in trouble. I believe that if the coal-miners of that State received the same treatment as the coal-miners of Queensland there would be fewer industrial disputes there. So long as we have arbitration judges like the individual who said that he would not know a coal-mine if he fell down it, we shall have trouble. I do not attack the honesty of purpose of such judges, but I contend that they are incapable of doing the job that needs to be done.

The honorable member for Bendigo said that the Labour party was affiliated with the Communist party. That is absolute " bunk ". The Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. Ward) has been accused in this House of telling lies, but gentlemen of the political kidney of the honorable member for Bendigo are those who tell the lies. In the last State elections in Queensland, Mr. F. W. Paterson, the Communist, opposed Mr. E. J. Braddon, M.L.A., the Labour man; and the honorable member for Kennedy (Mr. Riordan) also has been bitterly assailed by Communists. The policy of the Communist party is to white-ant the industrial movement. The

Labour party does not believe in the destruction of life, and it is opposed to Communist methods. In 1934 the Communist party of Australia decided that it would not oppose Labour party candidates at elections but would assist to return them to Parliament, but if, after their return, they failed to do what the Communists desired them to do the Communists would oppose them by every means in their power. I believe that honorable members will admit that I am not an opponent of the present Prime Minister ("Mr. Curtin). I have always been a sincere supporter of the Labour movement; but, I was the first Labour candidate in Australia to be opposed by a Communist; the second was the honorable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr. Johnson). I was opposed because I honestly believed, and have said publicly, that the Communist party desired to burst up the Labour unions of this country, and wished to begin by destroying the Australian "Workers Union, of which I have been a member for many years. Both the honorable member for Kalgoorlie and I have been executive' officers of that union. I have been opposed by the Communists also because I have told them that I consider the present leader of the Russian people to be the most active individual murderer on earth, not excepting even Hitler. I do not mean that he, as an individual, destroys life, but he is the leader of the party which has no hesitation in destroying life to achieve its own purposes. That is not the policy of the Labour party. The members of the Communist party have been instructed by Dimitrov, their leader, to make every effort to secure representative positions, though not paid office, in the Labour unions and particularly in the Australian Workers Union, which is regarded as a key organization. The purpose of these individuals in endeavouring to secure such office is to control the distribution of literature and the like. They wish to engage in propaganda favorable to their own views and to prevent the distribution of unfavorable literature. For that reason they lose no opportunity to seek appointment as shop stewards, and representatives on other jobs. I understand that I am going to be opposed again at this election by Mr. Paterson, and some of the friends of honorable members opposite may think fit to vote for him, giving him their second preferences if not their first. They did it against Mr. Dick Riordan, and I do not know of any reason why they should not do it against me. Their votes were cast against the Labour party and not against Dick Riordan personally, or at least, that was the excuse that they made. I have no illusions about their intentions. They are not going to oppose in this election any men other than those who opposed the bill extending the area of operations of the Militia Force. I did not oppose it. I voted for it and did not speak against it. Other members of this party spoke against it, and are not being opposed by Communists in Queensland. I do not make any complaint of that. I know what the Communists want. If there is affinity between any sections of the community it is likely to exist between members of the Opposition and the members of the Communist party, whose first desire is to destroy the Labour party. The honorable member for Melbourne has in his possession a placard issued by the Communists in favour of Dr. O'Dea, and urging the electors to support the Curtin Government. That is an extraordinary thing for them to do. I do not believe that Dr. O'Dea is a supporter of the Curtin Government, because he is really a disruptionist. I do not believe that he will speak in favour of the Curtin Government, as the placard says he will. I do not believe that the Prime Minister or any other member of this party has any illusions about what the Communists stand for. I have been attacking them for a good many years and shall continue to do so, so long as I have the strength and ability, for I do not believe in their methods. Stalin would not have come into the war on the side of the Allies but for Hitler hitting him "below the belt". The wonderful assistance that we are getting from Russia would not have been given to us if Germany had not attacked Russia. If Russia to-morrow dropped out of the war, it would again trade with Germany and provide it with oil and munitions to use against the allied nations. When the war started, the Communists were just as much in favour of conscription as are honorable members opposite. When. Russia had beaten Finland, and Russia and Germany had carved Poland up between them, the Communists were quite satisfied. They approved of Russia attacking Finland, because Mannerheim, the leader of the Finnish army, was a Nazi. When Stalin made his trade pact with Germany, all that the Communists in Australia said was, " hands off Russia ". They went so far in stupidity that at a conference in New South Wales, Dr. Lloyd Ross, when a motion was moved that no troops be sent overseas, moved the addition of the words, "including Communist Russia ".

I should like to know how these people are able to purchase a newspaper for £25,000, of which £12,000 was paid in cash within a week, and to offer something like £S7,000 for a big building- in Sydney. Are they entitled, under the National Security Regulations, to pay £25,000 for a newspaper? I could not spend money to build a home without the consent of the Treasurer. I do not know where the Communists get their money from. I do not think it comes from subscriptions from Dr. O'Dea and other Communists like him. I did have an idea at one time of where they got it, but I was not sure.

We heard something about aerodromes and strategic roads to-day, and the ex-Minister for Air (Mr. McEwen) got very " hot under the collar " when we said that these essentials to defence were not in existence when his Government was in office. They had not been provided to any extent then. They have been built with remarkable speed by the Civil Constructional Corps, working every day on shifts. The Opposition was never very much in favour of the construction of roads in the Commonwealth. The Stevens Government in New South Wales refused to contribute anything towards the cost of a proposed road from Hay through Queensland to Darwin. Mr. Forgan Smith, the then Premier of Queensland, said that his Government was prepared to find 50 per cent, of the cost of the portion through Queensland. That was a fair and right attitude, but the New South Wales. Government, which was of the same political colour as the Opposition in this chamber, was not prepared to pay anything, and so the project fell through. Aerodromes have been built in my electorate since this Government took over. I remember the Mackay aerodrome, when the only plane that could land on it was a Stinson, and then only in good weather. I worked hard to get that aerodrome extended and properly drained, with the result that to-day a plane can land there in any weather. The same thing is true of the Bowen aerodrome. When the late Mr. Fairbairn was Minister for Air, I asked, that aerodromes be built at intervals of 50 miles in that area. I did not know much about aerodromes, but the man who advised me did. I was so well advised that the late Mr. Fairbairn and the late Mr. Street walked across the chamber and congratulated me on the information I had given in my speech. I told them that it came from a pilot named Cook. Mr. Fairbairn told me that the greatest nightmare he ever experienced was in flying a plane from Cooktown to Townsville. He could not tell whether he was over Cairns, he was flying blind and very high, and all that he knew was that he was going south. After leaving Cooktown, he did not see a spot of earth all the way until he found himself 30 miles off Townsville. I asked the Government to erect signal stations, which was not done. However, since this Government has come into office that route has been made safe. Many aerodromes have been recently built in that area and the number of men working there in the last twelve or eighteen months has been very large. When I last saw Mr. Theodore, he told me that he wanted 15,000 men to put on an urgently necessary job in the north of Queensland. Nobody who knew that country as I have known it would have believed possible the enormous transformation that has taken place there in the last twelve months. Thousands of men have been working on the Atherton tableland and in other northern areas constructing roads, aerodromes and everything else required. Townsville, which in normal times has a population of 30,000, now has S0,000. One can hardly realize the enormous changes that have taken place in that area. Let me say something for the people doing these jobs. They are not on strike, but not a word is said about them by the Opposition in this Parliament. The comfortable well-fed men in this chamber who are able to go home to good beds and good meals, ought to be told that thousands of men are working the clock round on various jobs, and no strike ever takes place among them. The railway men, particularly in Queensland, are doing a tremendous job. On the north coast line, anywhere above Rockhampton, seven or eight trains a day used to be big traffic. To-day there are 70 trains and more travelling to the north and back every day. The men work from 18 up to 26 hours at a stretch without a break. Then they get a break of eight hours if they are lucky, and go back to work. Many times they do not get sufficient food, because of the stupidity of places being closed down by man-power officers who are square pegs in round holes. In that respect they resemble some of the men in this House. I have nothing against any individual who is doing his work, but when I see a man pushed into a job for which he is not fitted, I think that there is something radically wrong. The position everywhere is very difficult. Honorable members hear little growls, but the people of North Queensland have greater reason to growl than those in the south, because of the enormous distances. Trains- in Queensland to-day are running eight and ten hours late on the average. That is true of almost every train, because there is only one pair of rails and the distances are great. It is a long way between crossing stations where trains can pass each other. These difficulties arise because of the enormous distances and the small population of the State. New South "Wales has a comparatively big population, and shorter distances to cover. These men are doing a wonderful job with very little grumbling, but not a word is said about them in this Parliament. There are members here who know what the railway men in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia are doing, without any one talking about it. The enormous number of trains running are not peculiar to Queensland, because all the freight has to be taken to that State from other places. Not a word is said either about other men who are working hard in clerical positions in the railways of Queens land. I know quite a number of the men who work at the head office at Townsville, and I said to Mr. Hudson, the general manager there, " I never saw your clerical staff with the look on them that they have to-day. They look pretty tired ". He replied that it was no wonder, having regard to the hours they were working. Yet some people say, " But look at the money they are making". [Extension of time granted.] God help them, because they are jeopardizing their health to such a degree that the older men at least will be lucky if they ever recover; yet we do not hear honorable members opposite saying that these people are doing an excellent job. Not one member of the Opposition has said a kindly word about them. In almost every walk of life to-day men and women are working much longer hours than usual, and when I hear people saying, " Think of the money that they are making " I spit blood. The workers do not want the money. I have many friends over 50 years of age who started work in the Queensland Railways and in other undertakings as boys. They are still there, and they are suffering greatly under present conditions. They do not want the extra money ; most of them wish to God that they could take a week off and sleep. I -know that long hours and hard work are not peculiar to the railway men. These conditions are being endured by many thousands of workers in all forms of employment. There has been talk of " go-slow " tactics, and figures have been cited in this House of the time taken to load ships of certain tonnages, but not one word has been said about the stupid bungling which has necessitated entire cargoes being removed from ships because they had been loaded on to the wrong vessels. In these circumstances, surely the waterside workers cannot be blamed if the loading of ships takes much longer than it should. I have no illusions about honorable members opposite. By and large, in Australia to-day the people are working very hard, and when I heard the honorable member for Wentworth (Mr. Harrison) - I hope that he will never again be the honorable member for Wentworth because Ave hear from him nothing but abuse and filth - ask where would members of this House be but for the boys in

New Guinea, I felt inclined to ask him where would this country be without the men and women who are producing the food and munitions required by our troops in the battle areas. I do not detract from the valuable services that are being rendered to Australia by our fighting men; but I contend that the workers of this country generally also deserve some recognition, and when a man makes a statement such as that made to-day by the honorable member for Wentworth, he must be either stupid or worse and I do not think that he is stupid. The men and women on the production front in this country are working long hours and achieving wonderful results. American authorities here were staggered to find that the men at Cockatoo Dock were able to repair boats in half the estimated time. They are doing that not because of the money that they are receiving, but because they appreciate the value of their work in our war effort. Many of them have brothers or sons in the fighting forces and the last thing they want to do is to see our soldiers suffering unnecessary hardship. I do not believe that the men in the coal mines strike for nothing. Notwithstanding the fact that Russia claims that the Comintern has been disbanded, I do not believe it, and despite the strenuous efforts of the Communists in this country to convince us that they are behind the Curtin Government, I do not believe them. I believe that they are largely responsible for the industrial troubles that are occurring and I see no reason why I should believe their protestations of friendship. I know their history too well, and I know what they say in their official publications and propaganda pamphlets. I do not believe that Russia is honest in the dissolution of the Comintern. I have no illusions about that. I believe that Russia's object is to win for the Communists throughout the world, and while I have life in my body and the ability to express myself I shall do my damnest to stop them.

talk.start.para: .- I support the motion of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Fadden). I have listened, with great interest to the debate during the past two days and have heard some very able speeches, but I have also heard a lot of sheer misrepresentation. Much has been said about the achievements of various governments during the past two or three years. My view is that all these administrations have done a very good job. It cannot be denied that the Menzies and Fadden Governments did excellent work in laying the foundations of the great war effort of this country. And this Government also has done well in building safely upon the foundations which were so firmly laid. However, I see no reason why Labour should claim all the credit for what has been done. It has merely carried on the torch that was lit by its immediate predecessors in office. It has carried that torch high and well and I am prepared to give due credit for what it has achieved, but that it has now lost the confidence of the people and this House is beyond any doubt. One can hear that opinion expressed far and wide amongst all classes of people. Six or seven months ago the Curtin Government was held in high regard, but to-day the story is different. There has been too much bungling in industry. I know full well that industrial disturbances are unavoidable when a country is at war, but in Australia these disturbances have been overdone. Also there has been too much interference with the rights and privileges of the people. It is true that people cannot expect to live normal lives at a time when the young men of this country are fighting on our battle fronts; the Government has had a job to do, but in carrying it out there was a need for common sense and shrewdness. Some of the men who to-day are in charge of the production of foodstuffs and primary products generally know nothing about the job, yet they seek to tell practical men who have spent all their lives on the land how these industries should be run. Men in the national service office are carrying out a responsible and unenviable job and to a certain degree they are doing it quite well, but when they leave the theoretical side of the administration and endeavour to tell practical men what they should do it is an entirely different story. They do not know the first thing about such matters as the sheep carrying capacity of properties. The food situation in this country is one of vital importance. The Prime Minister's recent statement that the Government had had to choose between a possible shortage of foodstuffs in a year's time or a lack of man-power in the armed services and essential industries, shows that he has no practical experience of these matters at all. We must have food for our civil population as well as for our fighting forces. If men are taken from our primary industries, who is to say that in twelve months time they can be put back into those industries? During that period the industries may have been completely disrupted and thrown into a state of chaos. From the point of view of wartime efficiency, Australia's primary contribution to the allied war effort is best expressed in terms of food production. As one who has spent practically a lifetime in close contact with primary production and who has had a little ministerial experience of that production expressed in terms of war potential, I contend that Australia's basic duty is to provide food for the fighting forces and for its own civil population. All other efforts are dependent upon that being done, and failure in that task will mean that all other achievements will be negatived. We cannot fight without food ; our civil population cannot provide the basis for a war effort unless there is an adequate food production; food cannot be produced without experienced labour. Unfortunately the brains directing our war effort have sought to reach a climax without first ensuring that basis. In other words bureaucratic bulldozers have bemuddled this nation into an imitation of much larger nations, forgetting that a sound economic framework can be built only on a secure foundation. These are the troubles with which we are confronted. By way of contrast I shall read the views expressed by the Minister for Agriculture in the British Parliament -

quote.para: Plan ahead of crops, milk and meat production. Work out what feeding capacity your farms will have in 1943 and 1944 and see that none of it is wasted; rear all the calves you can, and keep up your sheep stocks to the limit of feeding capacity. The notion can do with all you can produce. However good your crops, however much you are getting from your livestock, it is not enough. We need still more. The most vital thing is wheat. Every acre of land capable of growing wheat must be sown to wheat.

speech.para: The man who made that statement is a member of a government which obviously understands the realities of war production. It is plain to every one in this country that the production of food for the Australian population as well as the fighting forces is an urgent need; yet what do we find? Because of the urgency of the moment clerks elevated to positions of responsibility are in charge of a situation about which they know very little. Gould anything be more tragic? I have had personal experience of the work of these bureaucratic experimenters, and with dire results. I have been told by a sheltered civil servant employed in a department which has no contact with primary industries that women in small numbers are able to perform work which, as a practical man, I know can not be performed by men in large numbers. The primary industries of this country have been denuded of their manpower to a tragic degree. Industries are being crippled and primary producers are being practically f orced off their holdings. I appealed to the national service officer and to the man-power authorities in Sydney, pointing out that one man had been left in charge of two properties of 6,000 acres with only his wife to assist him. The man-power authorities asked him whether an incapacitated man, or a man incapable of doing a full day's work, would be of any value. Obviously, he would not be suitable. Some of these primary producers have four or five sons in the Army, but are unable to secure the release of even one of them for the purpose of increasing the production of food. Whatever the physical capacity of the farmer may be, one man cannot work a property of 4,000 acres, keep it free from noxious weeds, exterminate the vermin and perform the hundred and one tasks that require to be done on a farm.

talk.start.para: - It has been done.

- It cannot be done, and properties are falling into a state of decay. As the result of the decline of food production, the health of civilians may suffer in the future, and the requirements of the Army might not be met. These failures cannot be attributed to war conditions. They are the direct result of inefficient administration. Ordinary common-sense knowledge of primary production and its relationship to man-power would have obviated this disaster. Former Army officers and trade union secretaries do not understand the problems of primary production. They lack the necessary practical experience. Aided by hot-house products of the Public Service, they can only be expected to muddle a reality, as an elephant would trample an etching. Postwar reconstruction under these conditions is the mouthing of a monumental misunderstanding, mauled by the misconceptions of these experimentalists. In the process, primary production is being killed. If the Government harms primary production and starves it by depriving it of man-power, all the plans for reconstruction will be idle words. The post-war view is even more murky. Whatever we plan after the war, primary production must be the first consideration.

speech.para: As the result of the decline of the dairying industry, the Government has been obliged to ration the supply of butter available to the civil population. More than 1,000 dairy farmers have ceased production, and valuable dairy herds which were established many years ago regardless of cost have been destroyed. When Japan entered the war, the Government became panic stricken and depleted the dairying industry of man-power, regardless of the consequences. The farmers had no course open to them other than to dry off the cows and sell them to the butchers. Is it any wonder that production has decreased? The decline must be attributed to maladministration. I recommended to the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. Ward) the appointment in various districts of small committees consisting of from three to five men to work in co-operation with the national service officers, who lack practical experience of rural problems. Ultimately, these committees were established and have worked fairly satisfactorily. Unfortunately, there is no relationship between the demands of the Army for man-power, and its requirements of food. I agree that the Women's Land Army is performing excellent work. Generally speaking, farm work is heavy because it involves carrying bags of wheat and superphosphate, the handling of horses and many other jobs which are not women's work. Many of the women can do these jobs as efficiently as men. At the same time, the balance between the fighting forces and the producers who have to feed the troops and the civil population is uneven. That is why the people are dissatisfied. The Government has been guilty of maladministration.

In the establishment of the munitions industry and the Allied Works Council, the Commonwealth Government has performed a great work. When I mentioned a certain factory in my electorate the Minister for Munitions interjected in a manner which suggested that he took the credit for the whole of the success. He stated that when he visited Albury he was tendered a civic reception and a deputation waited on him. That is characteristic of Albury and of other towns in the same electorate. The people will tender a civil reception to a Minister of the Crown when he is worthy of it, and I have great respect for the honorable gentleman. But his job was not to establish the factory. He did not lay the foundations of the works. He had to make a decision between several sites, because a dispute had arisen as to which should be selected. Mr. W. J. Smith had recommended certain positions, and when an agitation arose in connexion with their respective claims, the deputation asked the Minister to make the selection. His choice was a wise one. My object in making this explanation is not to cast a slur on the Minister, but to remind him that he should not take the credit for laying the foundation of that splendid factory. Incidentally, a substantially bigger factory had been promised to Albury, but through the wisdom of Mr. Essington Lewis, a site for it was selected near a. capital city. Mr. Lewis pointed out the inability of Albury to accommodate the large number of workers who would be employed in the factory.

I regret that the Labour party has consistently declined to join with the United Australia party and the United Country party in forming a national government. The people desire it and if the Labour party had accepted the offers that the right honorable member for Kooyong (Mr. Menzies) made to it, the present political disunity would have been avoided. The Minister for Labour and National Service is responsible for creating the controversy regarding " th Brisbane line ". In my opinion, the issue should be fought by those who know the facts. I have only to say that for twelve months I was a Minister in the Menzies and Fadden Governments, I attended every Cabinet meeting, but I never heard a reference to " the Brisbane line ". When the right honorable member for Kooyong was Prime Minister he created the Australian Advisory War Council consisting of the right honorable member for Darling Downs (Mr. Fadden), the right honorable member for North Sydney (Mr. Hughes), the honorable member for Warringah (Mr. Spender), and the honorable member for Indi (Mr. McEwen), representing the United Australia party and the United Country party, and the right honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Curtin), the right honorable member for Barton (Dr. Evatt), the honorable member for West Sydney (Mr. Beasley), the honorable member for Hindmarsh (Mr. Makin), and the honorable member for Capricornia (Mr. Forde), representing the Labour party. All matters relating to strategy were submitted to the' Australian Advisory War Council, and if the plan for " the Brisbane line " had been in existence, the representatives of the Labour party would have been aware of it. It is untrue to say that the plan was conceived by the previous Government. The Prime Minister should have been more frank and manly than he was when he said that the plan had been " presented to his Government ". That is not enough. If he had admitted that the plan had not been propounded until Japan had entered the war, he would have stood high in the estimation of the people instead of being discredited as the result of his evasiveness. An independent authority should be appointed to inquire into the allegations in. order that the truth may be revealed to the public. I was astounded to listen to the discussion about who is responsible for our war effort. There has been talk of the accomplishment of our fighting forces, of the men of the Army, the Navy and the Air Force. We talk of the Battle of the Coral Sea, and of the Battle of the Bismarck Sea. This Government claims the credit for practically all that has been achieved, and some credit is due to it, but when we consider the matter impartially, we are forced to admit that nothing less than the hand of Providence has saved us. The honorable member for Herbert (Mr. Martens) spoke of Stalin and his armies, and he wondered whether Russia would now be fighting on our side had not Germany attacked. I am perfectly certain that Russia would not have been in the war had it not been attacked. I am sure that if Hitler' had not made that tremendous blunder, but. had instead taken his forces into North Africa, through Egypt and thence into Asia Minor, we should not have been in the fortunate position we are to-day. It was the finger of Providence which directed him along what was for him the wrong track. If Japan, instead of attacking the United States of America, had turned its attention first to Australia as an easier mark, we would now have been enslaved instead of being, as we are, a free people. Again, it was the hand of Almighty God that protected us.

talk.start.para: - It was pretty rough on the Filipinos; we must have been given preference.

- The Filipinos were the victims of a cowardly attack by a ruthless enemy. I had not intended to say anything on the subject of communism to-night, but references have been made to it by speakers from the other, side. The honorable member for Herbert (Mr. Martens) referred to the activities of the Communist party which is erecting buildings and founding newspapers in this country. I condemn the Government for having lifted the ban on the Communist party, thus allowing it to publish its own newspapers in the capital cities, and to disseminate its poisonous literature among the people. I spoke on the subject of communism until the Minister for External Affairs (Dr. Evatt) told me that he was becoming embarrassed. I asked him questions on the subject which he said he could not answer because they involved matters of policy. I say that the Government is steeped in communism. The Communists have been refused affiliation with the Labour party, but that has not prevented them from infiltrating the movement. If they have been checked at the front door, they have poured through the back door and through the windows. The Government has sold out to the Communists, who are anti-God and anti-everything else that is good. This Government deserves to pay the penalty reserved for any government which tolerates the Communist party. That party is opposed to all our Christian traditions, and the Government which tolerates it deserves to be kicked out of office. I am convinced that when the Government meets its masters at the poll it will be told in no uncertain terms what the people think of it. We are satisfied with the great Christian empire to which we belong. The Minister for War Organization of Industry (Mr. Dedman) has admitted in published statements that he is a socialist. As a matter of fact, socialism is being practised in Australia to-day. Small businesses are being closed, and there is unnecessary interference with people. We are suffering from the application of these foreign doctrines by people who are filching from us the privileges for which we are fighting. Men who have established small businesses in country towns, giving employment to one or two persons, men who have married and committed themselves to the building of a good home through a building society, have been told to get rid of their stocks, to close up their businesses, and go into camp. One national service officer said that that was no worse than taking a man out of a £600 per annum job, and putting him into camp. It is infinitely worse, because the salaried man can return to his job, but the man who loses the business which he has worked for years to establish will never be able to get the capital together to start another when he returns after four or five years' service. The Communists have smothered the Government and the Labour movement. Those who look to the Labour movement for protection have no remedy, because the Government has allowed the Communists to take command of their organization. The ban cannot be reimposed now, because things have gone too far. If an attempt were made to reimpose it, the Communists would sabotage every industrial undertaking. They snooped to the Government until they got the ban lifted. Now they are embarking upon ambitious schemes to found a university in Melbourne, and to establish schools for the training of commissars. They are reputed to have offered £S7,000 for a building in Sydney in which to establish a school to carry on their confounded work. It is a disgrace to the country that this should be allowed to happen. The Government deserves to lose the confidence of the House. I support the motion.

. - I understand that I am the thirty-eighth speaker in this debate. I have very little to add to the flood of oratory that has deluged the chamber during the last two nights. That flood was enough to wash away " the Brisbane line " and " the Moore line ", and any other line, real or imaginary, which has been mentioned as representing the boundary of our defensive military activities. Whatever " the Brisbane line " controversy may have revealed, it is undeniable that Australia was in such a hopeless condition militarily from March, 1941, until March, 1942, that there was no hope whatsoever of beating the Japanese if they had attacked us in force. Not only would we have bad to abandon all of northern Australia in order to fight on " the Brisbane line but we should probably have been unable to fight on any line at all, not even on one running from Newcastle to Adelaide. It was only when General MacArthur came here some time after Japan attacked Pearl Harbour, and large forces from the United States of America, instead of proceeding to the Philippines, were diverted to this area, and two Australian Imperial Force divisions were brought back, that there was any hope of our being able to defend ourselves. A few months later, General MacArthur moved his troops, Australian and American, not to "the Brisbane line ", but right into the heart of Papua. That army ensured our safety from attack, and for that we have to be thankful. It was due to Providence and good luck, more than anything else, that we survived the danger of that period between 1941 and 1942.

speech.para: In a Parliament where the Government has now a majority of only one,, and in which, the Opposition is determined to express ite lack of confidence in the Government at every opportunity that presents itself in the time that remains before the life of this Parliament expires, it seems obvious to me that *hose who should decide all questions of confidence in the Administration a,re the electors of the Commonwealth, and they should be given the opportunity to do so without delay. The only way out of the present impasse is to have an early election and I have no doubt what the result will be.

In the few moments which I propose to use, I wish to answer some observations made during- the course of the debate. The honorable member for Wentworth (Mr. Harrison) said in effect that General MacArthur had requested the Prime Minister (Mr. Curtin) to introduce conscription, Nothing could be further from the truth. General MacArthur has never, so far as I have been able to learn, attempted to interfere with the domestic policy of this country. He has given a splendid example of proper behaviour towards the Government and the Army of the Australian people. His genuine friendliness towards this country makes him, although he is a citizen of the United States of America, a better Australian in fact than a number of members of this Parliament. He certainly has never attempted to interfere -with the methods by which we raise our Army. Although "the honorable member for Bendigo (Mr.- Rankin) did suggest that the Government was attempting to use General MacArthur for political purposes, it "was (perfectly clear that the honorable member for Wentworth was trying to misuse the name of a distinguished soldier and a great citizen of the world in- order to bolster up this motion of want of confidence.

The right honorable member for Cowper (Sir Earle Page) said tha-t we w-ere lu0,00t) men short on the food front. If that figure is correct, the situation is deplorable, and should be remedied immediately. I know that there are shortages on the food front, that there is butter rationing and milk rationing, and that we are denied cream. I know that many other things to which we are accustomed, and which we should be able to produce in abundance, are lacking. I hope that our economy will be so organized soon that we shall be able to produce a surplus of foodstuffs for export to Great Britain, and also to satisfy the needs of the Australian community. There should be no necessity for a shortage of any primary product in a land like Australia. The right honorable member for Kooyong (Mr.' Menzies), shortly after the formation of his National Service Group, indicated that those honorable members who supported him in disagreeing with the policy that had been pursued by the Opposition in recent .times considered that there should be no further increase of social services while the war lasts. I strongly dissent from that view. Unless we prepare for peace now, unless we overcome the present housing shortage and provide homes and employment for our soldiers upon demobilization, there is certain to be grave social, political, and maybe industrial upheavals in the post-war world. I proudly take my stand with those who have issued a Christian programme for social justice in the names of the Anglican Social Questions Committee, Catholic Action, and Christian Social Order Council. This council represents & number of organisations, and the following churches: Australian, Baptist, Churches of Christ, Congregational, Latter Day Saints, Methodist, Presbyterian, and Society of Friends. I may add that this programme does not necessarily express the complete or official view of any of the churches concerned. The programme outlines a set of principles, with general and detailed application, which in the view of the Christian people who prepared it, should have general application. With the permission of the House, and in order to save time, I shall include it in Hansard without reading it. It is as follows: -

quote.para: CHRISTIAN COLLABORATION
Suggested Points aron Common Programme.
The Common Programme which is suggested is based upon the Five Points relating to the internal social order which were agreed upon by the - English Church leaders who met at Malvern, England.

The Programme represents an attempt to work out a practical application of these points to present-day Australian conditions. The aim has been to make the programme sufficiently specific and detailed to enable us to rebut the accusation that we are concerned only with the dissemination of abstract principles, and yet sufficiently wide to enable vis to reach a general agreement. As democratic and Christian citizens facing the necessity of a new world order, we are convinced that -

item.label: A.
item.para: -" Extreme inequality in wealth and possessions should be abolished." (Point One)

quote.para: General Australian Application
Property should be used in accordance with
Christian principles, and should not be so abused that property and power are increasingly concentrated in the hands of a monopolistic few, and thereby divorced from the masses.
More Detailed Application

item.para: The Public Control of Monopolies. All industries which have reached the monopoly stage, or which are so important in the national economy that their control by private individuals might endanger the common good, should be publicly controlled.

The Public Control of Credit.- In the productive process we recognise the interests of three parties - the producer, the distributor, and the consumer. We maintain that money or credit are not commodities, but simply means of exchange. In the national interest we proclaim our belief that credit should be publicly controlled, c.f., " the monetary system shall be so administered that what the community can produce is made available to members of the community, the satisfaction of human needs being accepted as the only true end of production" (Malvern Conference).

The Institution of Industrial Councils. - " The status of man as man, independently of the economic process, must find expression in the managerial framework of industry; the rights of labour must be recognised as in principle equal to those of capital in the control of industry" (Malvern Conference).

quote.para: To effect this Industrial Councils should be developed in each industry. They should bo developed organically from below, and not imposed from above. They should be self-governing bodies, which should control all the operations of each industry - including wages, prices, dividends, and profits. They should be endowed with plenary authority to fulfil their proper functions. They should be composed of representatives, in equal numbers, of workers and employers of their respective industries and of the general public.

These Industrial Councils should be subject to the co-ordinating power of the State, which should ensure their proper subordination to the common, weal, but should not infringe the properly exercised self-government of these Councils.

item.para: Assistance to Small Owners. - During the period of transition from individual to co-operative effort, effective measures should be taken by the State to protect small shopkeepers and tradesmen from undue competition from chain stores and department stores and mass production methods.

Part Ownership of Industry for the Workers. - " The existing industrial order, with the acquisitive temper characteristic of our society, is largely responsible for the problem of the ' mass man,' who is conscious of no status, spiritual or social, who is a mere item in the machinery of production, and who easily develops the herd psychology, which is automatically responsive to skilful propaganda" (Malvern Conference).

quote.para: In the opening up of new industries and the reorganisation of existing industries, the workers should be given an effective share in the ownership, control and profits of the industry.

Co-operation. - Legislative, financial and technical assistance should be given to movements aiming at the spread of co-operation in all its aspects - producers', consumers', marketing and insurance co-operatives, and credit unions.

item.label: B.
item.para: - " The family as a social unit must be safeguarded." (Point Three)

quote.para: General Australian Application
All men should be given the assurance of a livelihood for themselves and their families, under conditions befitting their dignity as sons of God.
More Detailed Application

item.para: Recognition of the Principle of Adequate

quote.para: Income for All, including those on the land.

item.label: i.
item.para: The minimum wage received, supplemented as hereinafter suggested, should be sufficient to enable all to -

item.label: (a)
item.para: Secure proper maintenance for themselves and their families.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Have the opportunity of acquiring adequate amounts of. property for themselves.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Make suitable provision, through public or private insurance, for periods of illness and for old age.

item.label: (d)
item.para: Improve the cultural condition in which they and their families live.

quote.para: The better to achieve these we suggest:

item.label: ii.
item.para: The Payment of a Marriage Bonus. This should be paid (on marriage) by the State to enable all to purchase in part their homes and furniture.

item.label: iii.
item.para: The Payment of Adequate Family Allowances. These should be paid by the State as an addition to wages, to enable the recipient to maintain his wife and each of his dependent children. The payment should be made by the State in the form of a family allowance, which should be adequate for the maintenance of each recipient concerned.

item.label: iv.
item.para: TheRight to Adequate Income Must Be Assured to All : " Inasmuch as human status ought not to depend upon the changing demands of the economic process, no one should be deprived of the support necessary for the good life ' by the fact that there is at some time no demand for his labour " (Malvern Conference) .

quote.para: Failing the provision of work, the family wage should be the provision of all those who are willing to work.

item.para: Wages shall come Before Dividends and Profits. -

item.label: i.
item.para: In all machinery of wage-fixation there should be complete recognition of the principle that wages are the first charge on industry.

item.label: H.
item.para: Equal Pay for Equal Work. - To prevent the exploitation of female labour, the principle of equal pay for equal work should be recognised.

Possession of Family Homes by All. - " In all that is planned, regard must be paid to the family, as, by God's appointment, the basic social unit on whose stability and welfare all other social welfare in large measure depends" (Malvern Conference).

quote.para: All should be able to possess their own family homes on blocks of land each adequate for normal family needs. The machinery to provide this should ensure that all are able effectively to exercise this right.

item.label: C.
item.para: - " The resources of the earth should be used as God's gift to the whole human race, and used with due consideration of the present and future generations." (Point Five)

quote.para: General Australian Application

The reconstruction of agriculture shall be based upon the concept of the land as a way of life, and national policy shall be directed against those vested interests and noxious policies which derive from the exploitation of the soil and natural resources primarily for commercial returns.
More Detailed Application

item.label: I.
item.para: Decentralisation. -

item.label: (a)
item.para: To preserve the family life of the rural population, a consistent policy should be adopted of establishing new industries in country areas.

item.label: (b)
item.para: All ports, roads, and rail systems, the use of which would combat the present excessive centralisation, should be utilised" to the full, and any transport facilities provided in the future should be planned with a view to decentralisation.

item.label: (c)
item.para: A programme of rural housing should be undertaken to equip country homes with the conveniences of the city - electricity, sanitation, water supply, refrigeration.

National Campaign for Family Land Settlement. - Governments should inaugurate a vigorous policy of land settlement. Large estates capable of subdivision, land ' being operated for absentee landlords, especially for financial institutions, should be resumed by the Government and made available to those who wish to earn their livelihood on the land.

Freedom from the Thraldom of Debt. - " The existing industrial order tends to recklessness and sacrilege in the treatment of natural resources. It has led to the impoverishment of the agricultural community " (Malvern Conference).

quote.para: Adequate moans should be taken by the public authorities to prevent the sale of land at inflated prices.

item.label: (a)
item.para: All debts owed by farmers to the State, financial institutions and private creditors should be re-examined and remitted, either wholly or in part, in accordance with the real value of the land and the amount which has already been repaid. The objective of this measure should be not merely to. tide the rural community over a temporary crisis, but to place it on a sound and permanent financial footing, allowing the farmer to practise his craft as a way of life, and not as a commercial exploitation of the soil.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Interest on loans should in future be limited to a percentage which is equitable in the light of reduced financial returns for primary products.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Since the home and property of the farming family belongs not only to one, but to all generations, its use as security for newly contracted debts should be completely forbidden. Adequate measures should be taken by the public authorities to prevent the sale of land at inflated values.

Independent Farming. - "We must recover reverence for the earth and its resources, treating it no longer as a reservoir of potential wealth to be exploited, but as a storehouse of Divine beauty on which we utterly depend " (Malvern Conference).

quote.para: The objective to be placed before our farmers is that they should no longer regard the farm as a mere source of products to be sold for profit, but that they should set themselves a twofold objective:

item.label: (i)
item.para: To live as far as possible off their own land, by producing as much food as is possible for the family's requirements.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: When this has been achieved to produce a diversity of products for sale rather than only one or two, so that the hazard of financial insecurity shall be lessened.

Co-operation in Agriculture. - Special emphasis should be placed on the necessity for co-operation throughout the rural community, as a means of reducing the present excessive costs with which agriculture is burdened:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The State, on its part, should provide, in whatever regions possible, new plans of irrigation and water conservation so that this objective may be achieved. These should be freed from any exorbitant charge to the farmer, and should be financed as public works enriching the nation as a whole through helping the rural community to be placed on a firm and stable basis.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The State should provide whatever further financial and technical assistance may be required to enable production to be diversified, and so to lessen the dependence of farmers on the overseas market, which has been fraught with so much disaster for them in the past.

item.label: G.
item.para: Fair Return for Farm Products. -

item.label: (a)
item.para: In the sale of their products farmers should be guaranteed a price based on the cost of production and a return reasonable to their exertions.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The assurance of a fair return for their products should enable farmers to pay an adequate wage to their employees.

The Self-government of Agriculture. - To avoid the menace of excessive individualism on the one hand, and State domination and bureaucracy on the other, the direction of agriculture shall be in the hands of a Rural Council, which shall be composed similarly to the Industrial Councils, and shall enjoy similar autonomy and legislative powers to those provided in Clause 3.

item.label: D.
item.para: - " Every child, regardless of race, or class, should have equal opportunities of education suitable for the development of his faculties." (Point Two)

quote.para: *' The sense of a Divine vocation must be restored to man's daily work." (Point Pour)
Detailed Application

item.para: National System of Education. - "We regard as of primary importance the securing to all children and adolescents and educational opportunities best suited to develop their faculties and to enable them to take their full share as Christian citizens in the life of the community - economic, cultural and spiritual " (Malvern Conference).

item.label: (a)
item.para: Adequate financial provision should be made to ensure that every child, regardless of race or class, shall be entitled to equal opportunities for a full education, with assistance, if necessary, to maintain the child while the period of study is proceeding.

item.label: (b)
item.para: In the general cultural background of education - historical, literary, social and economic - proper emphasis should be placed on the nobility of all work of social value.

item.label: (c)
item.para: This involves the adoption of a policy of providing appropriate technical training, whether in industry, on the land, or in the home.

Religion, the Basis of Education. - While coercing none, and according liberty of conscience to all. we maintain that the only right foundation of education of life is Christianity. No system which ignores this essential is in accord with the full needs of the human personality.

quote.para: And to the achievement thereof we pledge ourselves individually and corporately.

speech.para: I conclude with, the statement, taken from last night's Melbourne Herald, that the housing shortage in Victoria now totals 60,000, and that it will increase by 8,000 a year while the present restrictions last. The position is even worse in New South "Wales than in Victoria. I hope that at aoa early date the Government will give serious consideration to the matter of providing relief. I believe that if that he done, by greatly relaxing, restrictions on the building of new houses, we shall have many more friends in the election campaign which I see impending, than otherwise would be the case.

talk.start.para: .I support the motion. I have followed the debate with considerable interest. A noticeable feature of it has been that the Government has adopted tile tactics of counter-attacking, the Opposition. Militarily, those are extremely good tactics. It has done so, for the very good reason that it has no sound arguments with which to counter the arguments and criticism of the Opposition. It has produced all the weapons in its armoury. Short of artillery, its weapons have consisted of squibs and stink bombs. It has followed the lead of the German high command, by having brought forward a new invention, in the very capable hands of the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. Ward). I need hardly mention that this takes the form of a purloined letter. This offensive spirit of the Government on the floor of the House is very interesting from a psychological point of view, because, from past experience of Labour, we know that it is an extremely pacifist party; of all the parties in this country and most other countries, it is the most pacifist. That cannot be contradicted. It has not been particularly pacifist in this House, especially during the course of this debate ; but in past decades in the history of Australia, it has been consistently opposed to any improvement of our defences that has been projected from time to time by former governments. It has charged the two preceding governments with having neglected the defences of this country. Unfortunately, it is true that, when war broke out, our defences were entirely inadequate. There is one very good reason why the defences of Britain and the Dominions were at that time in such a poor condition. After the last war, the determination was arrived at to endeavour to bring about disarmament in the world. Great Britain and all of its Dominions followed the policy of disarmament in the hope that they would set an example which would be followed by other countries. Such, however, was not the case. Almost too late, we 'became aware of the dangers that confronted the British Commonwealth, of Nations. When preceding governments woke up to what was occurring, and introduced budgets for defence purposes^ they were strongly opposed by the Labour party. Yet to-day the Government not only accuses the Opposition of failure to place the defences of this country in good shape, but also charges the two preceding governments with, having been defeatists. I could understand such criticism being levelled at the present Administration. But how is it possible to accuse of defeatism a government which sent our troops abroad, in order to defend Australia not within its own borders but far from its shores? Surely criticism, if any, should be that it had been too offensive in spirit rather than defeatist, and the charge of defeatism should be levelled against the party that occupies the Government benches! The Government has been afraid to send our troops beyond the shores of Australia. When honorable members opposite sat on this side of the House, they adopted a policy of isolationism - of keeping our troops within the confines of our own country. That must be construed as defeatism, rather than the policy of sending our troops abroad to take part in battles with the enemy where he wa3 to be found.

speech.para: The point which the Government has chosen for a counter attack is an airy one which means nothing. It is founded on, encompassed, and supported by untruths. In effect, it is nothing. I do not propose to discuss the essence of those untruths, because an explanation of them has already been made by many of the speakers who have preceded me from this side of the House. I have, however, been greatly surprised at the attitude that has been adopted by one member of the Government. I have always understood that lie was a follower of Karl Marx, and had studied the doctrines of that gentleman. This has been evident in the speeches he has made to the country at one time and another. But when he follows the dictates and precepts of the arch-Fascist of the world - Hitler - with such care, one begins to wonder how many works he has studied. One of the precepts to which I refer is to be found in Hitler's work Mein Kampf - the bigger the lie, the more often it is spoken, the greater is the effect which it has. When the Minister for Labour and National Service produced the story of " the Brisbane line ", and other inventions, obviously he had in mind the lesson he had learned from his friend, the Fuhrer. I do not propose to deal further with " the Brisbane line ", or the subject of defeatism.
I wish to refer to primary production, and the manner in which it has suffered at the hands of the present Government.
There is no question that since this Government came into power primary production in this country has gone downhill.

talk.start.para: - What reason has the honorable member for saying that?
- If the honorable member looks around him, he will see what reason I have.
- What statistics can the honorable member give in support of his contentions ?
- If the honorable member will come down to my part of the world, I shall furnish evidence in support of my contention.
- I have been in all parts of Australia, and can say that the honorable member's statement is not true.
- If the honorable member had listened to the speech delivered to-day by the Minister for Commerce and Agriculture (Mr. Scully), I do not think he would make such a statement.

- I intend to reply to the speech of the Minister for Commerce and Agriculture by reciting facts in relation to my own district. The trouble with him, in common with many other honorable gentlemen who sit on the other side of the House, is that he is not in touch with the realities of the situation. Since the Government came into power, the primary industries of Australia have rapidly gone downhill. The prices which the producer has to pay for all his requirements have increased by percentages up to 50 per cent, and more.
- So have the prices of his commodities.

- Essential supplies are not available to him in anything like the quantity that he needs. Often, he experiences considerable delay in obtaining what he requires. There are deficiencies in my district of chaff, bran, pollard, horse shoes, and boots. All these articles are required by the primary producers but they are either entirely unavailable or can be obtained in only small quantities. On the other hand, the prices received for primary products have not increased in the same ratio as the cost of requirements has increased. The price of ail primary products with the exception of wheat and wool, already dealt with, should be increased to an amount in keeping with the increased cost of production. Unfortunately, the primary producers are being hedged round with undue and unnecessary restrictions. Instead of recognizing this fact, the Government is increasingly interfering with the primary producing operations. I have given some attention to the book, The Federal Guide, referred to yesterday by the right honorable member for Kooyong (Mr. Menzies). I find that it includes the names of no less than 33 boards or committees which directly affect primary products, and three or four others which indirectly affect them. The Prices Commissioner also exercises control over a wide range of primary products. The result is that the lot of primary producers has become extremely difficult. "Without doubt an excessive number of boards and committees is operating. Moreover, many of the members of these organizations have not the requisite expert knowledge to deal with the commodities which come within their control, and there is an almost complete lack of co-ordination between the various authorities. One committee may issue an instruction that another committee dealing with the same commodity knows nothing about. Transport problems have also been seriously increased by the activities of these authorities. The business of small producers engaged in operations on a limited scale has been seriously affected. Even such matters as the supply of vegetable seed and the rotation of crops are affected by rulings of committees, the members of which are not qualified to deal with the subject. The rationalization of road transport which may have become necessary in some areas has been undertaken on far too wide a scale. In some areas the one vehicle which has been giving a regular service has been taken off the road, and individual farmers have had to put half a dozen less suitable vehicles on the run. Payments for the potato crop have been outstanding for months and this has caused the small growers serious difficulty. The restrictions imposed by the Government and the multiplicity of instructions that have been issued have confused primary producers.

speech.para: While the primary producers have suffered these serious handicaps people engaged in secondary industries have had their position improved. The coalminers are receiving anything from £8 to £15 a week for 37£ hours work, yet many of them strike because they cannot get something that they desire. Persons engaged in other secondary industries are receiving as much as £20 a week, or more. I noticed a report in a Tasmanian newspaper recently to the effect that the average wage of persons in secondary industry in a certain area in which 11,000 people are employed is £256 per annum, whilst in primary industry in the same area in which 4,000 people are employed the average wage is only £202 per annum. The man on the land has suffered a serious diminution of income and is finding conditions harder in every respect. In the circumstances it is not surprising that he is dissatisfied with the Government which has been responsible for this state of affairs.

The dairy industry has been hit harder than any other primary producing industry. Last July a special committee appointed by the Government to make an investigation into the industry submitted an excellent report, the main recommendations of which were that there should be a general increase of 3$ d. per lb. in the price of butter, and 2d. per lb. in the price of cheese, that the industry should be declared a protected undertaking, and that dairy-farmers who have been called up should be released in order to return to their properties. After a delay of two months, the Government provided n miserable subsidy of £2,000,000 for the dairy-farmers, of which the industry actually received only £1,500,000. The report was then pigeonholed.

talk.start.para: - Did not a previous government receive a report on this industry three years ago and fail to act upon it ?
- The only assistance that has been given to the dairy-farmer3 in the last ten years has been given by this Government.

- I am dealing with the actions of this Government. My statement that the report of the special committee has been pigeonholed cannot be truthfully denied. It is essential that this industry be assisted. I am glad that at last an additional amount of £4,500,000, which may be adequate, ha3 been provided. In principle, I do not favour the payment of subsidies to industries, but I admit that there are arguments why a subsidy should be provided in this case. I regret that no provision has been made for an increase of the price of whole-milk.
- Is the honorable gentleman sure that the subsidy does not cover the whole-milk industry?

- My advice is that it does not. Negotiations have been on foot for some months in Melbourne with the object of securing an increase of the price of milk. A recommendation was made six weeks ago that an increase of 2d. a gallon should be granted, which would bring the price of milk up to ls. 6d. a gallon, but nothing has been done, although the circumstances of the dairy farmers at the moment are particularly difficult owing to the necessity of handfeeding cows in the winter months.
- What happens when the union makes an application for the increase of wages?
- The matter goes to arbitration.
- Similarly, this matter had to go to arbitration.

- It has been known for a very long while that an increase was necessary in the price of all dairy products. I am glad that the Minister for Commerce and Agriculture (Mr. Scully) has entered the chamber, for I can now make another appeal to him to give consideration to the request that has been made for an increase in the price of whole-milk. I have been informed on the best authority that it now costs lid. a gallon to produce whole-milk. I regret to have to inform the Minister that, while the Government has been tinkering at this industry, hundreds of dairy farmers have left their properties, which have been sold or leased for grazing or other purposes. An auctioneer in my own district told me that there had been a reduction of 6,000 cows in that particular area, which does not cover the whole electorate. Doubtless, the same kind of thing is going on in other parts of Australia.
- The investigations of the State Departments of Agriculture do not prove it.
- The statistical information of the State Departments of Agriculture is not correct.
- Is the honorable member in a better position than the State Departments of Agriculture to obtain reliable statistical information?
- The people who have provided me with my information are in a better position to do so.
- Ah!
- It is of no use for the honorable gentleman to say " Ah ! " The figures which I have stated are not guesswork.
- Inspectors are at work in every district keeping a check on the number of cows on dairy-farms.

- The meat industry as a whole in Australia has for months past been a plaything of the Government, which has set up one committee after another and transferred functions from one committee to another, until finally it looks as though some definite organization is approaching. Time does not permit me to go into the whole history of the matter since the Government first decided to take it in hand. I therefore propose to deal only with the action taken in regard to canned cow beef. From yesterday the price of canned cow beef was fixed at 4d. per lb. chilled weight, delivered to the cannery or cold store. Last week canning was costing the boners 39s. per 100 lb., subject to a deduction of 5 per cent. The price now offered to the actual producer is only 33s. 4d. per 100 lb. at 4d; per lb. in cold store, which is equivalent to 31s. 8d. per 100 lb. Newmarket, or a reduction of 7s. 4d. on the actual price given last week. With canneries paying 7d. per lb. for boned cow hinds and 6d. to 6$d. per lb. for boned fores, a 350-lb. carcass is estimated to yield £7 to the boner, or 40s. per 100 lb. On this basis, if canner cows cost the boners 37s. 6d. per 100 lb. at Newmarket, there is a clear profit of 2s. 6d. per 100 lb., or 8s. 9d. a cow. The producers feel that they are entitled to 37s. 6d. instead of 33s. 4d. per 100 lb. for ordinary cull dairy cows in canner conditio!*. If higher grades are required, proportionately higher prices should be paid, but this is not the whole story. No prices have been fixed for boned meat, and carcasses are to be delivered whole into store. This ruling has two effects. First, it increases the demands on the cold stores, because boned meat is obviously more economic to store than carcass meat. Secondly, all carcasses will under the present ruling have to go to the four big meat concerns, and the smaller man will be cut out of the business. The small man who has been getting from 7d. to 9d. per lb. for boneless cow beef will now get only 4d. He will thus lose his men engaged on boning, who will be taken over by the big firms, and when the lamb season comes there will be no boners to deal with beef. The whole effect of the order is to concentrate production in the hands of the larger firms, squeeze out the small man and destroy competition. What every body in the country wants to point out to the Government is that the Labour party, which has claimed to be the protector of the small man against big business, is now and has been for some time past favouring the latter.
- That is not true.
- I know of small men who have gone out of business as the result of the Government's rationalizing policy.
- I challenge the honorable member to name one specific case in which my department has closed down any small business.
- At any rate, the Government has done so indirectly, as the result of measures taken by the Minister's department.
