- I challenge the honorable member to state one specific case of that either.

- I will give the Minister a specific case later. As the result of the order that carcasses shall be sent to the big people, small people will now have to close down that class of business, because they will have no way of treating their meat. They will lose their boners, who will in turn go to the large concerns, and when the time comes that the big business concerns begin to work on the lambs, the effect of this Government's legislation will be to put the small firms out of business. The dairyman who above all should be encouraged will lose on account of reduced prices for his cull stock. The big man in the meat trade will gain at the expense of the small man. The history of this Government has shown that the Labour party is not out to protect the interests of the small man.

speech.para: Another instance is furnished by the recent rise of -Jd. per lb. in the wholesale price for mutton, and Id. per lb. for the retail butcher for legs. What will be the result of that ? These steps are taken by the Government on the advice of its officials, who in many cases have no real knowledge of the effects of the measures which are brought into force. The wholesale butcher, being allowed to charge Id. per lb. extra on legs will get 2s. 6d. more on a 60-lb. carcass. The retail butcher will have to pay an extra 2s. 6d. for that carcass, and is allowed to charge Id. per lb. extra on the four legs, which will weigh 12 lb. in a carcass of that size. He therefore pays 2s. 6d. more for the carcass, and recovers only ls. on the legs. This is another instance of the big man getting assistance at the expense of the small one. These things are causing a great deal of dissatisfaction throughout the country, and constitute some of the reasons why I propose to support the motion.

talk.start.para: .I rise to oppose the motion, and am surprised that it should ever have been introduced. One of my reasons for speaking is that the debate will be historical. I realize that the House has been debating the motion for nearly 40 hours, and I wish to speak on it only for the purpose of recording my protest against the action of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Fadden) in introducing a motion of want of confidence at this period in the history of the Commonwealth. The right honorable member used very extravagant terms when introducing his motion and then summarized it in five or six items. The first was inefficiency of administration because of inexperience and lack of ability. The Labour Government has shown no lack of ability and no inexperience in its handling of the affairs of the Commonwealth during its period of office. Quite apart from the general war activities of the Government and its work in endeavouring to conduct the economic life of the nation on a balanced basis, it has done a national and international job, and has even been selected by various allied nations to represent Poland in the negotiations to be undertaken with Russia. It has worked hard to bring about a scheme for postwar reconstruction. It has also introduced social services to provide satisfactorily for all sections of the community during this period of stress. The charge of inefficiency in administration and lack of ability made against the members of the Ministry cannot be substantiated. Man for man they compare favorably with the members of the Opposition. Contrast the present Prime Minister with the Prime Minister of the previous Government. Honorable members opposite should read what a newspaper which supported the United Australia party said of Mr. Curtin. I refer to the Sydney Morning Herald, which, in an article headed " Call to Unity ", published on the 21st March, 1942, said-

quote.para: Mr. Curtin is Prime Minister; he is a man unambitious but high principled, of considerable ability, stronger and more decisive than his quiet manner suggests, anxious to give any matter a calm and judicial decision, and above all, determined to win the war for his country and for humanity. We could not choose a better leader to-day. For us there are no parties. Mr. Curtin is Australia's leader. Mr. Curtin has various Ministers. Some of them are efficient, others are not. If Mr. Curtin can strengthen his team at short notice, well and good. If he does not, they are entitled every one of them to the undiluted loyalty, co-operation and constructive assistance of every citizen to the utmost.

speech.para: Those are the views of a newspaper which has for a long period supported the United Australia party. It is satisfied with Mr. Curtin's leadership. We on this side are definitely satisfied with it. Another heading in this article " Call to Unity" was "The Party Game", and this is what the newspaper said on the subject -

quote.para: With too many of us party politics is still being played. There are many who think that no good can ever come out of Labour. There are many who, if the Minister's way is not theirs, if they suffer hardship or injustice, feel justified in holding back a little.

speech.para: That is what is making the Opposition feel peevish to-day. The Labour party is doing an excellent job but some are trying to discredit the value of its work during its short term of office. I followed almost the whole of the speeches in this debate, and heard each Minister's reply when his department was attacked.

The Opposition has come out of this debate in a very poor light. Honorable members opposite have spoken of unnecessary government interference in industry; but in a time of war, how can a government avoid interfering with industry. That charge definitely is unfounded. My reason for speaking in this debate is because I consider the occasion historic. I have sat here throughout the proceedings and I am satisfied now that I have participated in the discussion in support of the Government. I am confident that while this war continues there will not be another similar motion moved in this Parliament.

talk.start.para: . - in reply - The debate on this very important motion commenced at 2.30 p.m. on Tuesday afternoon. In moving the motion I gave to the House several reasons why the Curtin Ministry was unfitted to control the destinies of Australia, and only a prejudiced mind could be consoled by the belief that the Prime Minister (Mr. Curtin) has answered adequately the charges that I have laid against his administration. The right honorable gentleman stated that the war transcended everything. That is a view that has been held by the Opposition since the outbreak of war in September, 1939, when an approach was made to the Labour party to form a national ministry as the requisite foundation for a maximum war effort. However, not only did honorable members opposite flatly refuse to give the desired co-operation, but they also refused to go to the aid of Great Britain in any way. They adhered to their policy that not one man, not one gun, not one plane and not one vessel should leave Australian shores to go to the help of the Mother Country. Could the days ever be darker or the prospects ever dimmer for the British people than they were in 1940 and . 1941 when France collapsed and the British troops were evacuated from Dunkirk. The fate of the entire Empire was in jeopardy and if ever there was a need for complete political unity throughout Australia it was then. In his speech upon this motion, the Prime Minister made no reference to the Opposition's many approaches in regard to the formation of a national government. He contented himself by saying, as did the honorable member for Cook (Mr. Sheehan), that the threat of invasion of Australia having been averted by the present Government, it was a disastrous state of affairs that :i. vote of no confidence in the Government should be launched by the Opposition. I remind the right honorable gentleman and those who sit with him that the days of 1940 and 1941 were much darker and graver than they are to-day, yet late in 1941 the Prime Minister, then Leader of the Opposition, launched what in effect was a censure motion against the Government led by me, and succeeded, with the aid of the alleged independent member for Henty (Mr. Coles), in securing control of the treasury bench. Yet honorable members of this House, and the people of this country generally, are asked to believe that this is the first motion of this kind that has been moved since the outbreak of Avar.
- The motion to which the right honorable gentleman has referred was not a censure motion.

- In effect, it was a censure motion, because it was an amendment to the Fadden budget which was vital to the very foundation of the financial structure of this nation. I remind honorable members opposite, therefore, that they did not become a government by a mandate of the people, but by a mandate from the " half-dollar " honorable member for Henty. I counter strongly the suggestion that the Opposition has taken advantage of the more optimistic war outlook in this country to launch its motion of censure. "We have been informed that Australia is safe from invasion; but Australia is not yet safe. There is still much to be done before we can relax our war effort in any way. If we are safe, then why are we appealing and squealing for aid from the United States of America and the United Kingdom, and why have we sent the Attorney-General (Dr. Evatt) overseas? We are not safe, and it is because the Opposition recognizes that the war transcends all things that I have moved this motion. We are aware that, because of the internal set-up of this country and the conditions on the home front generally resulting from the actions of this Government, our Avar effort is in jeopardy. We believe that Ave have a responsibility to discharge as a vigilant Opposition in this chamber. I repeat that the charges upon which the motion of want of confidence have been based have not been answered adequately. The propaganda that has emanated from the Government side of the chamber has been most effectively dealt with in speeches from members of the Opposition. Let us examine the facts : First and foremost, as the basis of his reply to my charges, the Prime Minister used the war position in Australia to-day. I remind the right honorable gentleman ' and those who sit with him that his Government inherited from its predecessor a going concern, so far as defence preparations are concerned. The foundations had been laid firmly, and as it was apparent that Japan might enter the Avar, it waS only logical that the greatest possible impetus should be given to the construction of a sound framework upon those foundations. It would have been suicid'al had such action not been taken. In 'that regard, I quote to honorable members the following observation made in the British House of Commons by the Prime Minister, Mr. Churchill, on the 2nd December, 1941, showing how a munitions programme operates: -

quote.para: First year, nothing at all ; second year, very little; third year, quite a lot; fourth year, all you want.

speech.para: According to that time-table, in the years 1939 and 1940 we should have produced nothing at all in this country, but should have been engaged merely upon the laying of foundations and the making of surveys. But what was the position in Australia? In September of 1939, we were thrown into a state of war almost overnight. We were a peace-loving community and Ave were confronted with the task of undertaking warlike activities including the manufacture of munitions. A foundation was laid, and I repeat that a going concern was handed over to this Administration when it assumed office. To say that Australia was defenceless at that time is unfair, unwarranted, and far from the truth.

The Prime Minister also recalled that a year ago he had stated that if he had to choose between the risk of being short of fighting-power in the next year and the risk of being short of food the year after, he would take the risk of being short of food. I commend to the notice of the right honorable gentlemen a passage from the memoirs of Mr. Lloyd George. It reads -

quote.para: Governments have the entire responsibility for the home front. That front is always underrated by generals in the field, and yet that was where the Great War was won and lost.

speech.para: The Opposition has shown clearly the position in which bungling on the foodproduction front has already placed us. I repeat that the home front is most important, and, as I said yesterday, whilst the Prime Minister has been able to control Parliament due to the co-operation of the Opposition, and to control its war activities because of the patriotism, determination and character of our fighting men, and the willing co-operation of a large body of patriotic Australians, it has not been able to obtain the wholehearted support of those nearest and dearest to it, namely, the trade unionists. The Government to-day is a partisan administration and cannot be otherwise, because it has to depend upon the trade union movement. Evidence of that fact was shown in connexion with the Militia Bill, and if confirmation be required, it is to be found in the reports of a recent conference attended by the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. Ward) and the Minister for Supply and Shipping (Mr. Beasley). At that conference, the Minister for Supply and Shipping appealed to unions and. said : " Please give us a go ". He appealed to unionists not to strike or absent themselves from their employment for the next three months in order not to prejudice the prospects of the Labour party at the forthcoming general elections. Obviously, the Labour .party has to obey the instructions of the Trades and Labour Council. I do not blame honorable members opposite; they have to honour their political pledges. But I do blame the people of Australia who elected them.

Ministers have attempted to defend the Government against the charge of having condoned industrial lawlessness. The Labour party has claimed considerable credit for having reduced the number of strikes since it took office, and the. Minister for Labour and National Service has from time to time compared the number of strikes that occurred during the Menzies and Fadden regimes with those that have occurred since the Labour party took office. Regulations have been gazetted to outlaw strikes, and Ministers have repeatedly threatened the industrialists responsible for stoppages ; but the fact remains that the latest available figures disclose a worsening of the position.

talk.start.para: - The United Australia party foments strikes, and we have to settle them.

- In the first quarter of this year, 268,299 working days were lost through strikes, compared with 378,195 working days for the whole of last year. Of the 268,299 working days lost in the first quarter of this year 125,000 occurred in the coal-mining industry, 92,000 in the -manufacturing groups, 25,000 in the building trades and 20,500 in land and sea transport groups. Those figures demonstrate that Australia is not getting a maximum war effort, and that political advantages, in the opinion of the Government, are more important than the winning of the war. As the Minister for Labour and National Service has made certain charges, I shall read a relevant passage from a statement issued on the 13th February, 1941, under the names of myself, as Acting Prime Minister, the then Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Curtin), and the then leader of the Labour party - non-Communist (Mr. Beasley) -

quote.para: We think we should tell the people of Australia that it is the considered opinion of the War Council that the war has moved to a new stage involving the utmost gravity. At the meeting to-day a complete review was made of the existing situation and its implications. These can only be described as of a most serious import. It is necessary to say that various contingencies within the next fewweeks have been taken into account and effective preparatory measures have been taken.

speech.para: Referring to this statement, the present Minister for Labour and National Service said in Parliament on the 13th March, 1941-

quote.para: The Acting Prime Minister knows that the Government issued the warning in an endeavour to hoax the public.

speech.para: When he was asked to withdraw the word "hoax", he substituted the phrase " unwarranted scare ". He declared further that the Commonwealth Government had no information which warranted the issuing of such a warning and that in his opinion the 'Government exploited the situation for political purposes. That was the view of the Minister in March, 1941. I invite the House to contrast it with his allegations against the Menzies and Fadden Governments of unpreparedness.

That Minister also alleged that I was prepared to sanction the evacuation of portion of northern Australia without firing a shot. To prove the falsity of that charge, I remind the House that, in my maiden speech on the 17th June, 1937, more than two years before the outbreak of war, I urged the Government of the day to consider carefully the defences of Queensland, a State which was extremely vulnerable. Emphasizing the importance of the efficient control of our northern waters, I mentioned that foreigners were illicitly fishing off the Australian coast. I declared that Queenslanders were mindful of the proximity of a certain race and that the Government should give careful consideration to the defences of that State. Is that the attitude of a man who had no regard for the safety of his native State?

Regarding the charge that the previous Government was defeatist in outlook, and left the country in a defenceless condition, I remind the House and the country that the Menzies Government appointed the Advisory War Council in 1940, and the Labour party accepted an invitation to appoint representatives. Its representatives were : The present Prime Minister (Mr. Curtin), the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr. Forde), the Minister for Supply and Shipping (Mr. Beasley), the Attorney-General (Dr. Evatt), and on occasions, the Treasurer (Mr. Chifley). The Advisory War Council met for the first time on the 29 th October, 1940, and has remained in existence ever since. The representatives of the Labour party were conversant with every aspect of our defence policy; the council was created for that purpose. They were most vigilant and most critical. It was an advantage that they were so. They discharged their duties most conscientiously. To say that the United Australia party was responsible for the defenceless condition of Australia is to utter an unfair and unfounded charge. If it were accurate, the Labour party must share the responsibility with the United Australia party.

talk.start.para: - The Leader of the Opposition cannot " pass the buck " in that manner.
-Order! I shall name the honorable member for Cook if he does not refrain from interjecting.
- On the basis of the information in his possession, the Leader of the Labour party made the following statement in May, 1941 : -

quote.para: I claim that the war has been prosecuted to the maximum of Australia's capacity. " Maximum " means " to the limit ". As recently as last January, the right honorable gentleman stated that the Government in office before Japan entered the war had displayed a great deal of energy in organizing and developing Australia's capacity to participate in the war. Those statements are to be accepted as honest and sincere, because they emanated from a man who sincerely accepts and discharges his responsibility to the people. Everything that could possibly be done was done by the previous Government, having regard to limitations imposed by such factors as time, assistance available, opportunity and. resources. Every honorable member would do his utmost for Australia, and it is poor propaganda to accuse the previous Government of leaving the country in a defenceless position. I have submitted sufficient evidence to prove beyond doubt that there is no truth in such an allegation. It is only necessary to read Hansard in order to learn who was responsible for laying the foundations of the work on which the present Government has built. After much persistence, the Opposition has succeeded in forcing the issue in regard to " the Brisbane line ", and honorable members and the people generally must now be convinced that the Minister for Labour and National Service has been convicted out of the Prime Minister's mouth of making false allegations. This, however, did not deter him from further indulgence in deliberate misrepresentation. He has continued his attack from a new angle. He said that he would not contradict or deny that the available records disclosed that the first plan was dated the 4th February, 1942, "but", he went on, "I am most reliably informed that one important report is now missing from the official files ". In effect, he says that there is no available evidence to indicate anything other than that the report regarding " the Brisbane line" first came under the notice of those responsible for its consideration on the 4th February, 1942.

speech.para: In a letter which I addressed to the Prime Minister on the 28th May, I stated -

quote.para: With reference to your recent letter to me in connexion with the " Brisbane line ", received by me in Brisbane yesterday, I now request you to arrange for the production of the following documents at the Advisory War Council meeting to be held in Sydney on next Thursday, the Srd June, 1943:-

All War Cabinet agenda and records concerning the "Brisbane line"; the War Council agenda and records on the same: the submission made by Sir Iven Mackay to the Minister for the Army referred to in your letter; the War Council minutes from the commencement of the war to the end of March, 1943, and all records or documents which are the basis of your letter to me.

speech.para: I asked for all the records, not for some of them. or only for those relating to the matter since the Labour Government came into power. The Prime Minister sent me an index of the documents, and granted me permission to view them, which I have done. As the Prime Minister stated then, the first information in connexion with, this infamous matter dates from the 4th February, 1942. In order to extricate himself from an unsatisfactory position, the Minister for Labour and National Service now says that there is .another document which, he has been reliably informed, is missing from the files. If so, somebody must be responsible for the removal of the report in question, and in the interests of national security that person should be found. It is the duty of the Minister for
Labour and National Service to help to find him.

talk.start.para: - I am doing that, and I will not want a week for it, as the Leader of the Opposition took to prepare his evidence for the Winkler inquiry.

- The Minister for Labour and National Service says that he will not want a week to get the information. Evidently, he must have known of the missing document when he made his first statement on the subject of " the Brisbane line ", and that was in October, 1942.
- The Leader of the Opposition said that no such line had ever been proposed.

- I said no such thing. The Minister for Labour and National Service is confusing me with the other two gentlemen. I know that the matter was discussed in February, 1942, and the Minister for the Army and I took a prominent part in the discussion. I remind the Minister for Labour and National Service that he ventilated this matter first in "October, 1942. Did he inform the Prime Minister and his colleagues that he knew last October that an important document was missing from the files relating to the subject? The Prime Minister should answer that question. The Minister for Labour and National Service must have known all about it when he made his statement in October. Why has he delayed until now to reveal the fact that an important document in the custody of the Government was removed six months ago from the official files?

speech.para: I demand of the Prime Minister, as head of the Government, that the Minister for Labour and National Service substantiate his charge with facts and evidence. If, as he has stated, the Minister has been informed that an official report is missing, who informed him? Is his informant to be allowed to go free and unchallenged? Until this matter is cleared up, members of this Parliament are under suspicion, and the security of the nation is endangered. The Opposition insists that the Prime Minister treat it as a matter of extreme urgency.

I conclude by saying that the Opposition has furnished ample evidence of the necessity for this motion of want of confidence in the Government.We have furnished evidence which has not been refuted, and which proves conclusively that politically, industrially, financially, socially and morally, this Government no longer possesses the confidence of the House or of the people of Australia.
Question put -

item.para: That the Government no longer possesses the confidence of this House.
That a copy of this Resolution be forwarded to His Excellency the Governor-General.

division.header.para: The House divided. (Mr. Speaker - Hon. J. S. Rosevear.)

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

quote.para: That the House, at its rising, adjourn to 4 p.m. this day.
